story:
Storytelling is a vital part of all communities- it is the very breath of a living, dynamic community.  Our project strives to engage with community storytelling as an art form that spans visual, musical, and verbal communication.

Who We Are

Corinne Elysse Adams is a writer, poet, and musician from Texas.  Her work has been published in many literary journals and she actively performs and travels with various music projects in Austin.

Shivani Gupta is a professional photographer and Indian Classical Mohiniattam dancer from Mumbai, India. Her diverse practices coalesce and influence one another, and in this way, her practice with photography reflects elements of performance art, and documentation.  Her photography has appeared in journals and magazines all over the world, and she has had exhibitions with many contemporary Indian artists.

Our Project

Our project started just over three years ago. Corinne and Shivani discovered an overlap in their art forms: a passion for using their art to transmit stories.  This evolved into a huge project, spanning three different geographical regions in India.  We lived with communities in the Himalayas in Ladakh, the jungle in Madhya Pradesh, and spent some time with weaving communities in the desert in Rajasthan. 

Shivani photographed the stories while Corinne worked with translators to render them into various literary forms, such as traditional poetry, short fiction, and more avant garde poems. 

Read more about the comprehensive project in the Times of India article here.

However, due to illness and lack of funds, our project was cut short and we were unable to finish our filming in Rajasthan.  The funding we raise here will enable us to finish this last step of the piece. This project has already begun to bloom into a beautiful multimedia, multi-disciplinary piece of storytelling. 

We have been featured as a collateral show in the Goa International Photo Festival and at Art*ry gallery in Kochi.  Verve Magazine chose us out of all the exhibitions in the Goa photo festival to feature in their magazine.  We hope to eventually bring the whole project to a broader audience through book format, translating the poems and stories back into their original languages, so that they can be enjoyed by the people who told them to us as well as on the international level.

The stories are gathered, translated, and ready to be filmed.  All that's left is the final piece of funding to help us cover our costs and to pay the people who are helping us.  We believe in the importance of supporting local communities, and in paying people fairly for their work and their time.  Shooting stories with us takes away from people's valuable time working in the fields or with their looms.  Therefore, it is incredibly important to us that people are compensated in a fair, sustainable way for their time and participation.

What We Need & What You Get

How we will use the funding

  • Travel and lodging costs to/in Rajasthan
  • Payment to the communities we work with in filming.

Perks

  • Handmade or hand-chosen items from India for our supporters (postcards, photography prints, etc), as well as personal thank-yous to everyone who donates.

The Impact

Many people think art is something generally limited to the city, to urban life-- and particularly to the more wealthy and privileged. In our project, we are looking for a meeting place between urban and rural, between international and local.  We are looking for meeting points between our own experiences as artists and storytellers, and the experiences of the people in these communities who tell us their stories.

When we shoot the stories, we work within the community to creatively make the scenes come alive, using local traditional clothing and materials, as well as working with people to make costumes out of found materials.  In Ladakh, we worked with a few kids with only trash bags, kohl, and some other odds and ends to transform them into talking crows from a fairy tale.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate any money, hey, we understand! If you have a minute, please pass on this project to anyone you think might be interested, and thanks for taking an interest!

story:
Who are we?

Hi! We are the Iron Monkeys, a collection of volunteer artists, metalworkers, dreamers and do-gooders. We are based in the Georgetown neighborhood of Seattle, but have our dirty primate fingers in cities and towns from Vancouver, BC, New York, San Francisco, and all the way across the pond to London. We believe that art should be an experience , and we endeavor with each piece we build to warm and welcome all who wander our way. For over a decade we have been building and burning art together and this year is no exception.

 

What the heck are we building this year?

Our piece is called The Plaza of Introspectus. It is a 60’ wide gathering space laid out in the shape of a compass with the arrows pointed inward. A flaming steel armillary on an 8’ pedestal will be the centerpiece of the Plaza. Metal benches and fire zen gardens fill the space offering rest and reflection.

 

Another gathering space, sweet! What’s new this year?

First off, we’re blacksmithing eight new benches. We are calling them gossip benches, designed to sit and talk face-to-face either about your burn or about all the the blacksmithing involved in this years project.

 

Like to play with fire? Well you are in luck! New zen gardens will be built and placed in the Plaza allowing participants of Black Rock City to draw in some fiery sand.

 

The biggest new thing we are building this year will be the armillary, which is the centerpiece of the Plaza. An armillary is a spherical astronomical map composed of rings, and the one we build is going to be big, be on an 8' pedestal, and be raging with fire at night.

Sweet! But what does the money go to?

 

We have a received a grant from Burning Man to pay for some of the creation of Plaza of Introspectus but, it doesn’t cover all of our costs. We are asking for an additional $12,000 to help bridge the gap. The money we raise from you fine folks will help pay for: transportation, steel, bolts, taps, welding gas, oxygen, lighting, storage for the pieces of the project, propane, and much more.

Help a Monkey out?

Now is when we ask you to help us! Any gift, from $1.00 to $1,000 helps us create this piece of art. We have a bunch of great rewards this year to entice you. Check them out out over on the right.

Thank you! THANK YOU! There is no way we could build this kind of big ass art without the support of our friends and fans. This is our 13th year in Black Rock City and it is thanks to all of our supporters (that's YOU!) that we have thrived for so long. We look forward to sharing our art  with the masses yet again, be it in Seattle, in Black Rock City, or beyond!

 

From the bottom of our rusty little hearts, thank you.

Risks and challenges

This is our 13th year building a project for Black Rock City, and we have completed our project on time, every time.

That said, things do happen. If we find ourselves in a crunch for time there are elements of the project we can simplify or cut out.

story:
Summary of the Project

Dean and Lauren were brought together by the Reel Asian Film festival to collaborate on a project.  

They had never met before.  

The project had to be a mix of dance and film, Dean repping the Film and Lauren/Alias Dance Project repping the dance.  

Dean and Lauren started having meetings, trying to figure out what kind of a project they wanted to work on.  Their brainstorming sessions included coloured blocks, diagrams, and other objects.  They finally decided they were going to rework Lauren's 'Restorative Structure' into an interactive film and dance performance piece. 

Lauren's inspiration for this piece came from her experience of watching the mind and body of someone very close to her be taken over by alzheimer's disease.  They connected on this subject matter immediately as Dean also had personal experiences dealing with mental disease in his family.  

TODAY... the only thing that is missing is the financial support to make this vision a reality.  Given the time, studio space, funding and the support of the fabulous artists that surround us, the potential for this project is endless.  

What we need and what you get!

We need the resources to complete the creative process and film production of this project.

All proceeds from this campaign will support:
-the production and post production of the film
-the rental of equipment and space
-THE ARTISTS (!!!)

Right now, our goal is low: $1500.00.  The reason is that if we don't reach our goal, Indiegogo will take an additional 5%  (they take 4%, no matter what) of the funds raised as a fee.  If we can raise $3000, we will be able to pay the artists what they deserve for their collaboration and contribution in rehearsals and in the editing room!  If we raise more than that we will reserve this money to help fund the next phase of the project!  That would be incredible.

We would be grateful for any contribution that you can make to this project.  A lot of little bits add up to one big bit.  

... if you are thinking about making a donation, we have a few perks to offer you:

For a $25.00 donation, you will be given recognition on the Alias Dance Project website.

For a $50.00 donation, you will be given recognition on the Alias Dance Project website and a trio of photographs taken in rehearsals of 'Restorative Structure'.

For a $100.00 donation, you will be given recognition on the Alias Dance Project website, a photo trio and two tickets to 'Makin' it happen: a funder', a party on October 19th at Trinity Video.  If your donation is made after October 19th, you will receive two tickets to Alias Dance Projects next fundraising event.

For a $250.00 donation, you will receive a personalized thank you video message from the team working on 'Restorative Structure', plus all of the perks listed above. 

The Impact

This is a milestone in our professional careers.  We are both inspired by each others mediums in our own creative practices and we have always wanted to work on an interactive dance/film project.  This is the first dance film that either of us have ever worked on.  Having the support of Reel Asian and a platform for our work to be seen is incredibly valuable.  We have built a meaningful working relationship with one another and have already been discussing all of the future projects we would like to work on.  This project is only the beginning, but beginnings are the most important piece of the puzzle.  

In addition to the professional development opportunity that this project has created for us, this project has also engaged:

4 Dance artists

1 Sound Designer

2 Film production assistants

In meaningful creative work.  

Other Ways You Can Help

We totally understand if you cannot help out at this time.  There are lots of other ways that you can still support this project.  

Check out other things we need below and see if you can lend a hand:

- Come to our Fundraiser

: https://www.facebook.com/events/487622631352217/

- Spread the word, share our campaign and Fundraiser event page

- Volunteer at our fundy

- Donate gift cards/raffle prizes or food to our Fundy

That's a wrap!  Thanks for taking the time to read to the end!
story_txt:
Summary of the Project
Dean and Lauren were brought together by the Reel Asian Film festival to collaborate on a project.  
They had never met before.  
The project had to be a mix of dance and film, Dean repping the Film and Lauren/Alias Dance Project repping the dance.  
Dean and Lauren started having meetings, trying to figure out what kind of a project they wanted to work on.  Their brainstorming sessions included coloured blocks, diagrams, and other objects.  They finally decided they were going to rework Lauren's 'Restorative Structure' into an interactive film and dance performance piece. 
Lauren's inspiration for this piece came from her experience of watching the mind and body of someone very close to her be taken over by alzheimer's disease.  They connected on this subject matter immediately as Dean also had personal experiences dealing with mental disease in his family.  
TODAY... the only thing that is missing is the financial support to make this vision a reality.  Given the time, studio space, funding and the support of the fabulous artists that surround us, the potential for this project is endless.  
What we need and what you get!
We need the resources to complete the creative process and film production of this project.
All proceeds from this campaign will support:
-the production and post production of the film
-the rental of equipment and space
-THE ARTISTS (!!!)
Right now, our goal is low: $1500.00.  The reason is that if we don't reach our goal, Indiegogo will take an additional 5%  (they take 4%, no matter what) of the funds raised as a fee.  If we can raise $3000, we will be able to pay the artists what they deserve for their collaboration and contribution in rehearsals and in the editing room!  If we raise more than that we will reserve this money to help fund the next phase of the project!  That would be incredible.
We would be grateful for any contribution that you can make to this project.  A lot of little bits add up to one big bit.  
... if you are thinking about making a donation, we have a few perks to offer you:
For a $25.00 donation, you will be given recognition on the Alias Dance Project website.
For a $50.00 donation, you will be given recognition on the Alias Dance Project website and a trio of photographs taken in rehearsals of 'Restorative Structure'.
For a $100.00 donation, you will be given recognition on the Alias Dance Project website, a photo trio and two tickets to 'Makin' it happen: a funder', a party on October 19th at Trinity Video.  If your donation is made after October 19th, you will receive two tickets to Alias Dance Projects next fundraising event.

2 Film production assistants
In meaningful creative work.

Check out other things we need below and see if you can lend a hand:
- Come to our Fundraiser
: https://www.facebook.com/events/487622631352217/

- Spread the word, share our campaign and Fundraiser event page


- Volunteer at our fundy

story:
Coastal Conservation Projects

I'm Glyn Macey, a British artist, writer and fundraiser. I'm pretty well known for my work with organisations such as RNLI, UNICEF, National Trust and Greenpeace.

In 2017 I completed work on my most ambitious artistic venture to date: painting my way around the coast of Arctic Svalbard, documenting the wildlife and climate changes affecting one of the most fragile environments on the planet.

No stranger to demanding projects over the last six years, I have also painted my way across America from New York to Los Angeles for UNICEF, circumnavigated the English coast producing 180 original paintings en-route for RNLI and crisscrossed the UK filming the television series ‘A Brush with the Landscape’ for Sky Arts. The projects have now raised well over £100,000 for the benefitting charities.

I love to get as many people involved with my projects as possible and over the last decade, with the help of many beautiful people around the world we have helped some truly great causes.

This is where I need your help!

What I Need & What You Get

In a nutshell I need to raise £500 ($825) towards travel costs, but more importantly I want to get as many lovely folks involved as possible, it's much more fun for me that way! And in return I have a delectable range of juicy goodies for you including exclusive Limited Edition prints, Original artworks, Books and Vouchers.

The Result

My goal is to paint 180 original artworks whilst traveling the English Coast, every one of which will be crafted into a set of signed limited edition prints helping to raise funds for one of the UK's leading environmental and coastal campaign charities Surfers Against Sewage and their PLASTIC FREE COMMUNITIES initiatives.

The year long trip will also see me deliver free demonstrations and talks to communities from Berwick upon Tweed to the Solway Firth (and everywhere in between!).

The project artworks and my travel writings will also be published as a set of three fully illustrated books.

To find out more about me, my work and the projects check out www.glynmaceystudio.com or www.glynmacey.com

To find out more about the vital work of Surfers Against Sewage and the Plastic Free Communities initiatives click over to www.sas.org.uk

Other Ways You Can Help

If you could share this campaign with your friends I will love you forever :)

story:
THE SECRET CITY IS LOVE! This is our annual fund-drive to support the powerful, transformational and inspiring work of the Obie-Award winning Secret City, a performance art ritual in NYC, LA and, as of this summer, Woodstock. We rely on individual contributions to keep our work alive. Please give at any level and receive some of the great, new swag we're making for next season to sell in our online store. You get it here first! If you've never been to one of our events, please read on for more info. And, if you're a fan of The Secret City, you'll enjoy reading about the visions we have for the future.

BUT, WAIT, DIDN'T YOU HOLD YOUR "LAST INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN EVER" LAST YEAR? Well, we thought so, seeing as we're now a big, ol, official non-profit BUT, it turns out that crowd funding is a really great way for us to raise money so we're gonna stick with it. There's some different accounting that takes place now that we're our own 501(c)3 - the money raised goes directly to our bank account and we provide our funders with tax write-offs directly.

BUT, WHERE DOES THE MONEY GO? We’ve been holding our one-of-a-kind performances in New York for 7 years, in LA for the past 2 years and, this summer we will have our first Hudson Valley event in Woodstock. But what exactly is it? The Obie committee said back in 2010, “It’s a salon, it’s a celebration, it’s a show….a ceremony without any dogma. A monthly event that builds connections among artists by offering them sanctuary, humor, beauty, and wonder.”

I CALL IT AN ARTISTIC TENT REVIVAL: all are welcome, we celebrate the creative spirit, and community is created on the spot. The events are pay-what-you-can and we provide free childcare. Each event has a different theme and is followed by a coffee hour with treats brought by community members. The events themselves are joyful and deep; we practice a form of artistic mindfulness – asking people to pay attention, to sing, to mingle, to look at what someone has made, to watch performances, to participate in community interactions, and, to laugh their asses off.

The Secret City is special in that, aside from the spectacle or theme or meaning, the event itself generates community.

AMAZING EVENTS - SO, WHAT ELSE DO YOU DO? I’d like to share some of the visions for how we might grow and, because they say people really like a plan with numbers, I’m going to call it My 3 Vision Plan for the Future of The Secret City. VISION #1: To take The Secret City to other cities around the country – Portland, Austin, San Francisco, Baltimore, Philadelphia, Minneapolis, Chicago and more – you get the idea, an entire network of art worshippers across the land. VISION #2: A radio version of The Secret City, weekly on public radio: featuring live music, the Secret City Singers, games and storytelling, meditation; the featured visual art would be on our website so those listening at home could interact with the service as it’s taking place. VISION #3: I want us to buy a place in the country, a retreat where we’ll start The Secret City Institute: part think tank/part artist retreat/part training center where people can learn what we do and how to do it in their own town.

ALL OF THESE VISIONS ARE COMING TRUE – they’re manifesting as you read this right now. And they are made more powerful by being witnessed by all of you – for they have left the isolated, mad chamber of my mind and reside in all of your mad chambers now, too.

Visions, however, must be built on solid ground. We must stabilize this organization. So, hold on, cuz I’m going to change it up – now I'm going to call it My 4 Vision Plan, and I’m going to move this to position #1. We have to build infrastructure. We have a ton of really amazing volunteers – and we couldn’t pull of what we do every month without them but, to really grow, we need a staff.

I'M GOING TO SHARE SOME NUMBERS WITH YOU: Our annual budget has hovered just below $75 grand for the last few years. This year, my aim is to meet that budget and, to add another $50k to it – a $125,000 annual budget. What the hell, let’s call that Vision #5! It's now a 5 Vision Plan! I’m getting crazy up in here!

BUT HOW CHRIS? HOW WILL WE MAKE THESE VISIONS COME TRUE? First, we’re kicking off this online fund-drive – it’s called The Summer of Love, cuz we’re all about love, and because we’re heading up to Woodstock this summer. The goal of the online fund-drive is $30,000 raised over the next 45 days. I hope you’ll share the link with your friends, give generously and spread the word. We have accomplished amazing things on a shoe-string! Imagine the future we are building together. We're also planning a party in LA in the fall - and we've just started writing grants. So, we've got things in the works.

Creating The Secret City has made me a better person – in the middle of each service, I feel my heart open, I see connections where before I may have felt separateness or bitterness, in other words, it makes me more loving. My hope is that it does the same for others. 

Thanks for checking out our campaign.

With love,

Chris Wells - founder/artistic director

story:
Latvija nepazūd, tas ir tikai sākums

Sveiciens tev, lasītāj, šodienā! Es esmu Elīna, tāda vienkārša meitene no laukiem. Pirms vairāk nekā diviem gadiem es devos prom no Latvijas, lai pieredzētu nezināmo un ieskatītos savas dvēseles arhīvos. Kāpēc tas man bija tik svarīgi? Jo es ticu, ka pasaule var mainīties tikai tad, kad tu velti laiku sevis iepazīšanai. Katru dienu es atklāju jaunas patiesības par sevi un pasauli un to visu esmu aicināta tulkot mākslas valodā. Saku, ka aicināta, jo man ir sajūta, ka kāds augstāks spēks mani virza, un mana kontrole un loģika vairs nav primārais lēmumu pieņemšanas rīks.

Es zīmēju ģeometriskas konstelācijas un, gluži vai kā senie latvieši zīmēja rakstus un magnetizēja tos, es ļauju šiem simboliem ienākt pasaulē arī tetovējumu formā. Tetovēšanas procesā es izmantoju adatu (bez tetovēšanas mašīnas) un, veidojot tetovējumu, lieku punktu pie punkta. Tas ir roku darbs, ko mācos šeit, Hamburgā. Papildus tam, es attīstu gaismas valodas mākslu. Kas vēl ir svarīgi: mājās es nebraukšu viena. Ar mani brauks Svens, mans izredzētais, kuram ir brazīļu asinis. Viņš ir baigajā starā par šādu dzīves pavērsienu, jo grib darīt, būvēt, attīstīt vidi mums apkārt. Ģimene: tas ir darāmo darbu sarakstā.

Godīgi, man vienkārši ļoti gribas uz mājām. Dzīvot laukos un nodibināt mazu ģimenes uzņēmumu. Redzēt, cik mamma priecīga mirkļos, kad viņa var darīt to, kas vislabāk padodas. Ieklausīties vecmammas padomos. Sajust atkal īstu zemi zem kājām. Vasaras naktī ēst upenes no krūma. Auklēt savus bērnus vidē, kurā uzaugām mēs. Man ilgu laiku ir licies, ka Latvija lēnām pazūd, bet tā ir ilūzija, no kuras es mostos, un es spēju to atzīt. Es beidzot esmu gatava būt tur, ar jaunām idejām un pārliecību, ka arī nekurienē var tapt lielas lietas.

 

Nopirkt automašīnu, atbraukt uz mājām un turpināt radīt

Lai nokļūtu Latvijā, mums ir nepieciešama automašīna. Lai es varētu izveidot savu mazo mākslas studiju, man ir nepieciešams pamatkapitāls. Tādai absolūtai caurredzamībai: uz Vāciju es neatbraucu pelnīt lielo piķi. Arī šeit, Hamburgā, es vēlējos būt maksimāli brīva, bet tas maksā. Pirmkārt, dzīvokļu īres cenas šeit ir pamatīgi gaisā, otrkārt, visiem ir jāmaksā obligātā veselības apdrošināšana. Ja tu esi pašnodarbinātais, maksā no sava maka divsimt eiro mēnesī. Kāpēc es to pieminu - tradicionālā medicīna nav mans jājamzirdziņš, un šo naudu es varētu ieguldīt savos mākslas projektos. Es sapratu, ka mana eksistence šeit absolūti nav rentabla, un mana dzīve ir kā  uz adatām.  

Šo gadu laikā es esmu pilnveidojusi sevi un attīstījusi savas prasmes, un sākusi būvēt dzīvi tādu, kādu man ir prieks dzīvot. Ar savu dzīves uztveri es esmu iedvesmojusi daudzus, kas ir saņēmuši manu mākslu, ģeometriskus personalizētus dizainus un tetovējumus. Es radu ar nodomu, un man ir svarīgi sadzirdēt otra cilvēka stāstu. Reizēm pietiek ar skatienu vien, lai ienirtu otra dzīlēs. Mani dizaini ir aizceļojuši uz dažādām pasaules valstīm Eiropā un Amerikā. Pagājušā gada laikā es paspēju uztetovēt desmitiem simbolisku tetovējumu, kas kalpo kā spēcinoši amuleti.  Šogad es pārdevu savu pirmo fizisko gaismas valodas mākslas darbu. Papildus veicu arī dažādus grafikas dizaina darbus (logotipu izstrāde, promo materiālu dizains u.c.), tomēr šobrīd izvēlos fokusēties uz savu unikālo mākslas izpausmi, jo es zinu, ka tas ir kaut kas īpašs.

Es strādāju no mājām, bet mana auditorija nav tikai un vienīgi lokāla. Mans mērķis: atvērt studiju/kafejnīcu Baltinavā. Lai vai cik jocīgi tas neizklausītos, bet, manuprāt, Latvija šodien ir izbraukājama vienā dienā. Galu galā — kas ir 4 stundu brauciens salīdzinājumā ar tetovējumu uz visu tavu dzīvi? Globalizācijas un digitalizācijas laikā cilvēki ir pieraduši visu saņemt pēc iespējas ātrāk, bet tas nav tas, kā es vēlos strādāt. Manās acīs vērtība ir ne tikai sasniegtais rezultāts, bet pats process. Nesteidzīgs, baudāms.  Veids, kā es tetovēju, ir pieredze, kuru vēlos piesātināt ar iespaidiem par lauku burvību. Mans tētis, aizejot citā pasaulē, laukos atstājis ļoti daudz rīkus un materiālus, kuri bez vīrieša zelta rokām pazūd. Savukārt Svens prot metināt, labot mehāniku un pat uzcelt māju, ja vajag. Plāni ir lieli, bet, lai turpinātu, mums abiem ir jābūt Latvijā fiziski. 

 

Mākslinieka lielākais izaicinājums

Lielu daļu savas dzīves es esmu ticējusi, ka Latvijā kaut ko sasniegt nav iespējams. Jā un nē — atkarībā no tā, kas ir sasniegums tavā personīgajā izpratnē. Jā, protams, apstākļi māksliniekam šeit nav paši labvēlīgākie, bet ir jāatceras, ka pašā augšgalā ir cilvēka griba un Augstākie Spēki (sauc to par Visuma spēku, Dievu vai kā citādi), viss pārējais pakārtojas. Mans lielākais izaicinājums ir iemiesot manu mākslinieka būtību un apgāzt priekšstatus par to, ka mākslinieks (jebkādā radošajā formā) nav īsta profesija un ar to neko nevar nopelnīt. Var. Ne vien man ir šāda misija, bet arī latviešiem kopumā: iemiesot savus talantus, atklāt spējas, kas dzirksteļo un ceļ sabiedrību. Pajautā sev: kāda jēga katru dienu iet uz darbu, kas neiegriež tavu enerģiju, beigās knapi savilkt galus un pa virsu tam nejust sevi savā ķermenī? Es izvēlos dzīvot citādāk un nojaukt robežas starp pieņemtajām normām un bezgalīgo cilvēka potenciālu.

 

Pateicībā dot atpakaļ

Tuvojas mana dzimšanas diena 17. martā, un šogad mana lielākā dāvana ir būšana mājās. Mūsu mērķis ir 9 000 eiro: automašīnai, ceļa izdevumiem un manas radošās darbības pamatkapitālam Latvijā. Izklausās riktīgi daudz. Rakstu šo skaitli, un piezogas kauns. Tomēr, es nebaidos prasīt atbalstu, jo zinu, ko es daru un kāpēc es to daru. Mans mērķis ir cēls un tīrs. Iegūstot šādu summu, es vēlos pateicībā dot atpakaļ (pie katras summas ir minēts pakalpojums, kuru piedāvāju tev, neaizmirsti izlasīt arī aprakstu)  Lai arī cik liels skaitlis beigās tas būs, nauda tiks ieguldīta jau iepriekš minētajos plānos.  Lēmums ir pieņemts — mēs dzīvosim Latvijā.

 

Iepazīsties ar manu mākslu šeit:

Mājaslapā (angļu valodā): www.archivedalchemy.com
Instagram :  @archived.alchemy
Pinterest : archived alchemy
Mans veikaliņš Etsy platformā: šeit

Lūdzu, padalies ar draugiem un pazīstamajiem ar šo kampaņu arī tad, ja šajā brīdī tas ir vienīgais atbalsts, ko vari sniegt. Tikpat svarīgi, cik savākt šo summu, ir tikt sadzirdētai, jo mana balss netieši runā daudzu citu mākslinieku vārdā.

No sirds pateicos,
uz tikšanos pavisam drīz!

Elīna
story_txt:
Latvija nepazūd, tas ir tikai sākums
Sveiciens tev, lasītāj, šodienā! Es esmu Elīna, tāda vienkārša meitene no laukiem. Pirms vairāk nekā diviem gadiem es devos prom no Latvijas, lai pieredzētu nezināmo un ieskatītos savas dvēseles arhīvos. Kāpēc tas man bija tik svarīgi? Jo es ticu, ka pasaule var mainīties tikai tad, kad tu velti laiku sevis iepazīšanai. Katru dienu es atklāju jaunas patiesības par sevi un pasauli un to visu esmu aicināta tulkot mākslas valodā. Saku, ka aicināta, jo man ir sajūta, ka kāds augstāks spēks mani virza, un mana kontrole un loģika vairs nav primārais lēmumu pieņemšanas rīks.
Es zīmēju ģeometriskas konstelācijas un, gluži vai kā senie latvieši zīmēja rakstus un magnetizēja tos, es ļauju šiem simboliem ienākt pasaulē arī tetovējumu formā. Tetovēšanas procesā es izmantoju adatu (bez tetovēšanas mašīnas) un, veidojot tetovējumu, lieku punktu pie punkta. Tas ir roku darbs, ko mācos šeit, Hamburgā. Papildus tam, es attīstu gaismas valodas mākslu. Kas vēl ir svarīgi: mājās es nebraukšu viena. Ar mani brauks Svens, mans izredzētais, kuram ir brazīļu asinis. Viņš ir baigajā starā par šādu dzīves pavērsienu, jo grib darīt, būvēt, attīstīt vidi mums apkārt. Ģimene: tas ir darāmo darbu sarakstā.
Godīgi, man vienkārši ļoti gribas uz mājām. Dzīvot laukos un nodibināt mazu ģimenes uzņēmumu. Redzēt, cik mamma priecīga mirkļos, kad viņa var darīt to, kas vislabāk padodas. Ieklausīties vecmammas padomos. Sajust atkal īstu zemi zem kājām. Vasaras naktī ēst upenes no krūma. Auklēt savus bērnus vidē, kurā uzaugām mēs. Man ilgu laiku ir licies, ka Latvija lēnām pazūd, bet tā ir ilūzija, no kuras es mostos, un es spēju to atzīt. Es beidzot esmu gatava būt tur, ar jaunām idejām un pārliecību, ka arī nekurienē var tapt lielas lietas.
 

Nopirkt automašīnu, atbraukt uz mājām un turpināt radīt
Lai nokļūtu Latvijā, mums ir nepieciešama automašīna. Lai es varētu izveidot savu mazo mākslas studiju, man ir nepieciešams pamatkapitāls. Tādai absolūtai caurredzamībai: uz Vāciju es neatbraucu pelnīt lielo piķi. Arī šeit, Hamburgā, es vēlējos būt maksimāli brīva, bet tas maksā. Pirmkārt, dzīvokļu īres cenas šeit ir pamatīgi gaisā, otrkārt, visiem ir jāmaksā obligātā veselības apdrošināšana. Ja tu esi pašnodarbinātais, maksā no sava maka divsimt eiro mēnesī. Kāpēc es to pieminu - tradicionālā medicīna nav mans jājamzirdziņš, un šo naudu es varētu ieguldīt savos mākslas projektos. Es sapratu, ka mana eksistence šeit absolūti nav rentabla, un mana dzīve ir kā  uz adatām.  
Šo gadu laikā es esmu pilnveidojusi sevi un attīstījusi savas prasmes, un sākusi būvēt dzīvi tādu, kādu man ir prieks dzīvot. Ar savu dzīves uztveri es esmu iedvesmojusi daudzus, kas ir saņēmuši manu mākslu, ģeometriskus personalizētus dizainus un tetovējumus. Es radu ar nodomu, un man ir svarīgi sadzirdēt otra cilvēka stāstu. Reizēm pietiek ar skatienu vien, lai ienirtu otra dzīlēs. Mani dizaini ir aizceļojuši uz dažādām pasaules valstīm Eiropā un Amerikā. Pagājušā gada laikā es paspēju uztetovēt desmitiem simbolisku tetovējumu, kas kalpo kā spēcinoši amuleti.  Šogad es pārdevu savu pirmo fizisko gaismas valodas mākslas darbu. Papildus veicu arī dažādus grafikas dizaina darbus (logotipu izstrāde, promo materiālu dizains u.c.), tomēr šobrīd izvēlos fokusēties uz savu unikālo mākslas izpausmi, jo es zinu, ka tas ir kaut kas īpašs.
Es strādāju no mājām, bet mana auditorija nav tikai un vienīgi lokāla. Mans mērķis: atvērt studiju/kafejnīcu Baltinavā. Lai vai cik jocīgi tas neizklausītos, bet, manuprāt, Latvija šodien ir izbraukājama vienā dienā. Galu galā — kas ir 4 stundu brauciens salīdzinājumā ar tetovējumu uz visu tavu dzīvi? Globalizācijas un digitalizācijas laikā cilvēki ir pieraduši visu saņemt pēc iespējas ātrāk, bet tas nav tas, kā es vēlos strādāt. Manās acīs vērtība ir ne tikai sasniegtais rezultāts, bet pats process. Nesteidzīgs, baudāms.  Veids, kā es tetovēju, ir pieredze, kuru vēlos piesātināt ar iespaidiem par lauku burvību. Mans tētis, aizejot citā pasaulē, laukos atstājis ļoti daudz rīkus un materiālus, kuri bez vīrieša zelta rokām pazūd. Savukārt Svens prot metināt, labot mehāniku un pat uzcelt māju, ja vajag. Plāni ir lieli, bet, lai turpinātu, mums abiem ir jābūt Latvijā fiziski. 
 
Mākslinieka lielākais izaicinājums

Lielu daļu savas dzīves es esmu ticējusi, ka Latvijā kaut ko sasniegt nav iespējams. Jā un nē — atkarībā no tā, kas ir sasniegums tavā personīgajā izpratnē. Jā, protams, apstākļi māksliniekam šeit nav paši labvēlīgākie, bet ir jāatceras, ka pašā augšgalā ir cilvēka griba un Augstākie Spēki (sauc to par Visuma spēku, Dievu vai kā citādi), viss pārējais pakārtojas. Mans lielākais izaicinājums ir iemiesot manu mākslinieka būtību un apgāzt priekšstatus par to, ka mākslinieks (jebkādā radošajā formā) nav īsta profesija un ar to neko nevar nopelnīt. Var. Ne vien man ir šāda misija, bet arī latviešiem kopumā: iemiesot savus talantus, atklāt spējas, kas dzirksteļo un ceļ sabiedrību. Pajautā sev: kāda jēga katru dienu iet uz darbu, kas neiegriež tavu enerģiju, beigās knapi savilkt galus un pa virsu tam nejust sevi savā ķermenī? Es izvēlos dzīvot citādāk un nojaukt robežas starp pieņemtajām normām un bezgalīgo cilvēka potenciālu.
 

Pateicībā dot atpakaļ
Tuvojas mana dzimšanas diena 17. martā, un šogad mana lielākā dāvana ir būšana mājās. Mūsu mērķis ir 9 000 eiro: automašīnai, ceļa izdevumiem un manas radošās darbības pamatkapitālam Latvijā. Izklausās riktīgi daudz. Rakstu šo skaitli, un piezogas kauns. Tomēr, es nebaidos prasīt atbalstu, jo zinu, ko es daru un kāpēc es to daru. Mans mērķis ir cēls un tīrs. Iegūstot šādu summu, es vēlos pateicībā dot atpakaļ (pie katras summas ir minēts pakalpojums, kuru piedāvāju tev, neaizmirsti izlasīt arī aprakstu)  Lai arī cik liels skaitlis beigās tas būs, nauda tiks ieguldīta jau iepriekš minētajos plānos.  Lēmums ir pieņemts — mēs dzīvosim Latvijā.
 
Iepazīsties ar manu mākslu šeit:
Mājaslapā (angļu valodā): www.archivedalchemy.comInstagram :  @archived.alchemyPinterest : archived alchemyMans veikaliņš Etsy platformā: šeit
Lūdzu, padalies ar draugiem un pazīstamajiem ar šo kampaņu arī tad, ja šajā brīdī tas ir vienīgais atbalsts, ko vari sniegt. Tikpat svarīgi, cik savākt šo summu, ir tikt sadzirdētai, jo mana balss netieši runā daudzu citu mākslinieku vārdā.
No sirds pateicos,uz tikšanos pavisam drīz!
Elīna

story:
Hello World!

My name is Katie Lemieux, and I am a graduate of two art degrees and currently pursuing my passion as a ceramic artist. I am 25 and in the application process of obtaining my Masters Degree in Fine Arts, so I may continue creating work that explores issues I am passionate about.

This campaign will focus on spreading awareness about female inequalities within our modern society.

Throughout my academic years as an artist, Ive noticed drastic inequalities women must face on a daily basis. It is my hope that by running this campaign, I am able to create a visual (based on YOUR support!) of just how unfair our societal system STILL IS TODAY!

What kind of inequalities am I talking about, and why should you fund my project? Here are a few good facts that drive my mission:

  • Girls in school are taught to "cover up" their bodies, instead of boys being  taught to respect the bodies of a female.
  • Birth control is still a significantly harder means of contraception to access (and more expensive) than condoms.
  • Periods are STILL something that girls are taught to be ashamed of.
  • Tampon and Pad companies focus on "hush-hush" marketing. (Ie. Quiet wrappers, discreet disposal, etc.)
  • Media perpetuates an unrealistic and unobtainable body image that dramatically damages the self esteem of young girls.
  • Because the term "She was asking for it." STILL EXISTS
These are just a few examples of what drives me to create art that speaks out against gender inequality.

WHAT YOU CAN DO!

For every individual $20.00 that I receive, I will make a hare in your honor. This hare will be a symbol of our fight against sexism. This hare will also be named after YOU, so your donation in itself will be a work of art. (Your name will be carved on the underside of the rabbit!) Males and Females alike, I encourage everyone to take part in this movement of equality!

Just think of what a whole room of rabbits will demonstrate!

(Donations lower than $20 will have the donators name included in my list of credits, which will be printed and posted along with the final piece, unless it is their wish to remain anonymous.)
 

What I Need from YOU

My goal is to reach $2000. That makes 100 rabbits! An army of 100 rabbits standing against sexism is pretty cool, in my opinion.
The money I raise will help me in my developmental costs (clay and kiln firing) and a portion will also be donated to struggling female business owners within my community.

$2000 isn't much when it comes to wanting to help out my community, but it's a start! If I don't reach this goal, the money will be put into a savings account for my next gender mission, and will continue to support the women and girls within my community.

YOU CAN BE A PART OF A MOVEMENT! BE A HARE!
(See bottom of pitch to read about why I chose the hare.*)

Challenges I Face

Making 100 rabbits definitely won't be an easy task, as it will use up a LOT of clay, which can get pricey. Kiln firing (to make the clay piece into a hardened sculpture) is also very expensive and uses a lot of electricity.
To add, it is never easy making a gender specific piece, as it often causes tension with people who don't necessarily share the same opinion. I have been reprimanded for making gender pieces in the past, and was told that "sexism is a thing of the past."

But we all know this isn't true!

So hopefully with your help, I will continue to create work that speaks out against gender inequality and sexism within our modern day society!

Other Ways You Can Help!

I understand that not everyone is in a place where they can contribute financially. That's okay! The point of my work is to get my message of inequality out there.
Here are a few ways to help out within your community:
-speak out against sexism! If you hear a female being harassed, defend her! (safely, please!)
-Refrain from using derogatory slang such as "p*ssy", "c*nt" and "b*tch".
-Be respectful when a woman is breastfeeding in public. It's her right!
-Do not stare if there is a woman in your area wearing short skirts or revealing cleavage. It's her body, and she deserves respect no matter WHAT part of her is showing. You would want the same.

Other tips to help along equality can be found here:
http://www.wikihow.com/Be-a-Feminist

So spread the word! Get excited! Help me reach my goal of abolishing sexism!
BE A HARE!

Thank You! :)

*The Hare often historically represents the sexual female, as well as a symbol of fertility. Ishtar  (often represented as a rabbit) is a Babylonian Goddess, representing sex, war, fertility and love.
*Rabbits within artistic and religious views are often connected with the Moon, Rebirth, and  Resurrection. These are qualities that also connect traditionally to the female.

story:
GIRL ON CANVAS 

Girl on Canvas is an artbook project by Pola Dwurnik. It will be a book about painting and its reception. It will show a new life of Dwurnik’s paintings, one completely uncontorlled by the artist – life born in the imagination of 30 outstanding personalities, e.g.: Ruth Mitchell, Denise Grollmus, Andreas Blaettler, Olga Tokarczuk, Joanna Erbel, Piotr Lachmann.

The book is both openly personal and bravely intimate. Subversive, rascally and girlish. A subtle riot.

 

EXCERPTS FROM THE BOOK

At first I try to silence them, to control them just as I’ve always tried to repress myself underneath. I try to speak in whisper to them, but they only grow stronger, start flashing more intensely, it’s unstoppable. And then I give up, let them keep firing off, let them keep exploding, let them keep twinkling across the flame colour spectrum. - from the text of Agata Araszkiewicz, Blowballs, Kites…

You have to inhale air and smoke deep into your lungs and then slowly change them into thoughts, conceptions, and theories. The more complicated, the better—the more impressive the names the theories get and the more effect they have on people. For instance, you have to come up with ways of imagining the unimaginable, you have to create the most entangled and inherently contradictory mental states, and you have to combine separate emotions into intricate complexes and syndromes—and then you can ponder and attempt to cure them, and explicate, express, and interpret them. - from the text of Olga Tokarczuk, Pola Dwurnik, The School of Smoking, Or a Concert in a Cave

I liked the piece, because it made me think of a refuge. I have a balcony overgrown with creepers, fruit bushes and a few flowers. When I sit or crouch there, I am cut off from the world, hidden, tightly surrounded by my green jungle, and when I stand up, I am bathed in light and visible (...). The figure in the painting is about to stand up, to enter a stage watched with anxiety, hurriedly painting her nails. The artist has entitled his painting The Paintress, which I suspect is self-ironic, especially that Pola Dwurnik’s work is often autobiographical. - from the text of Jerzy Szygiel, The Paintress’s Luggage

 

GRAPHIC DESIGN

The book-object received its form from MOONMADNESS– Dagny and Daniel Szwed, the designers of numerous beautiful publications, including this year’s catalogue for the Polish exhibition at the Venice Biennale.

THE BOOK WILL BE A POLISH&ENGLISH PUBLICATION

More about the book

AUTHORS

Agata Araszkiewicz, art historian, lives in Brussels, Paris and Warsaw

Andreas Blaettler, art historan, works at Schaulager in Basel

Emilie Buri, art historian, editor-in-chief of Das MuseumsJournal in Berlin

dr Andrzej Depko, sexologist, sex therapist from Warsaw

Roman Dziadkiewicz, artist, lives in Cracow

Joanna Erbel, sociologist, urban activist in Warsaw

Denise Grollmus, American writer and essayist

Michał Jachuła, art historian, curator at Galeria Arsenał in Białystok

Adam Jastrzębski Ixi Color, artist, street artist

Natalia Kaliś, art historian, lives in Warsaw

Izabela Kaszyńska, culture expert, editor

Artur Kinruwd, art historian

Michał Kozłowski, philosopher, lives in Warsaw

Wojciech Kozłowski, art historian, director of Gallery BWA in Zielona Góra

Piotr (Peter) Lachmann, poet, essayist and theater director from Warsaw

Ewa Łączyńska-Widz, art historian, director of Gallery BWA in Tarnów

Krzysztof Masiewicz, art collector, publisher from Warsaw

Monika Micewicz, art historian

Ruth Mitchell, essayist, culture lover from Liverpool

Daniela Pfeil, linguist, pastor, lives in Basel

prof. Maria Poprzęcka, art historian, essayist, lives in Warsaw

Maria Anna Potocka, art historian, director of the Museum of Contemporary Art Krakow MOCAK

Konstanty F. Szydłowski, philosopher, lives in Berlin

Jerzy Szygiel, independent journalist from Warsaw

Olga Tokarczuk, writer, essayist, lives in Wroclaw

Ewa Toniak, art historian and curator, lives in Warsaw

Krzysztof Visconti, filmmaker, journalist, lives in Berlin

Karolina Wiktor, artist, lives in Warsaw

Anna Zawadzka, journalist, activist from Warsaw

Oskar Zięta, industrial designer and collector, lives in Zurich, Wroclaw and Zielona Gora

Agata Świderska-Zięta, lawyer, art collector, lives in Wroclaw

HELP US PUBLISH THE GIRL ON CANVAS!

Help us gather the funds to finish the book and become the co-publisher of the Girl on Canvas artbook!

One girl and her canvasses – Pola Dwurnik, the editor and producers: Iza Kaszyńska, Agnieszka Wąsowska and Katarzyna Homan are working hard to get it published in Autumn 2013.

The book is a non-profit project (all earnings will be used to finance the publishing process).

We want to raise 10 000 EUR that we still need to finish the book (it is around 30% of the whole budget).

All contributors will be mentioned on the Girl on Canvas website.

Check it out!

HELP US PUBLISH THE GIRL ON CANVAS!
Help us gather the funds to finish the book and become the co-publisher of the Girl on Canvas artbook!
One girl and her canvasses – Pola Dwurnik, the editor and producers: Iza Kaszyńska, Agnieszka Wąsowska and Katarzyna Homan are working hard to get it published in Autumn 2013.
The book is a non-profit project (all earnings will be used to finance the publishing process).
We want to raise 10 000 EUR that we still need to finish the book (it is around 30% of the whole budget).
All contributors will be mentioned on the Girl on Canvas website.
Check it out!

story:
7 Artworks in this Beautiful Installation Pathway!!

  • Waiting:

  

While we interact with a lot of beautiful people around us, we forget to attend to somebody who has been ‘WAITING’ to be with us for a long time. Equally beautiful yet unrealized, amazingly sensitive yet untried, incredibly empathetic yet undermined. Our eyes and hence our inner soul are waiting to talk to us for a long time. Resident inside us is this incredible urge to know more on the outside and ignore our own self.

  • Open:

 



The process of being with yourself and experiencing the stillness of time is both rare and enriching. However, while being with oneself the artist raises a beautiful question which says: “Are we really our best friends!”? This question essentially asks another vital question: Are we really the same person that we see in the mirror on the book? Are we ‘OPEN’ enough to challenge our deep rooted denials to accept who we are?

  • For:

 

Do we realize the importance our own self reserves ‘FOR’ us in our life? Confusing so it might seem, the idea is very relevant. Once we realise that we are at equilibrium with our own self, the world has a special place reserved ‘FOR’ us! 

  • Incomplete:

Once we abolish the difference between ‘You’ and ‘I’, the artist urges us to wonder if we would ever think that the world may not exist without us. The artist says that the world is ‘INCOMPLETE’ without you! You are as important as anybody else in this world. You are born in this world for a special purpose which cannot be completed without you!

  • Irreplaceable:


You are peculiar and distinct from everybody else and hence you are virtually ‘IRREPLACEABLE!’ Your distinct mannerisms, behaviors and innate abilities define who you are. And what you are is what makes you both unique and indispensable.


  • Am:

Once you have understood the importance of yourself, the artist says, you can now define yourself. It would become very easy for you to know both yourself and the relevance of your own existence and you are ready to say: “I ‘AM’ both the relevance and the definition itself.”

  • Open:

The cognizance of your own relevance and the significance of defining your purpose of existence becomes a powerful force coupled with the amalgamation of you becoming one with your own self, leads you to a path where you are ready to make a ‘MARK’ on this world. 


Short Summary

Hi Contributors, 

This is Namrata Lodaya. I am a Fine Artist working on from Mumbai. I am very passionate about Art. I live and breathe Art. I have been practicing Fine Art since 2000. 

Campaign:

'You're Important' was an exceptional solo exhibition on Minimalism. The response for this exhibition was unprecedented. The viewers were absolutely mesmerized by the artworks they saw. I, now, wish to take this to a complete different level by exhibiting at the India Art Festival 2013. A chance to exhibit at the India Art Festival will help me reach out to a huge audience. Your contribution will immensely help a young talented artist to reach the hearts of thousands that shall be a part of this event. It has been my childhood dream to exhibit at a huge Art Fair like this.

About You're Important:

You're Important is an exhibition in minimalist style. It is an installation pathway that always involves the viewers. Viewers are always a part of each and every artwork of hers. Without the viewers her artworks are incomplete.

Existence is a phenomenon which needs realisation. The importance of understanding the relevance of one’s own existence is in itself equivalent to attaining the biggest prize of living in this world. As Friedrich Nietzsche says "I don't need anyone to rectify my existence. The most profound relationship I will ever have is the one with me."

Each one of us has his/her own relevance and purpose for existence. Through the various artworks displayed here, the artist wishes to take you through the journey of making everyone realize how their existence is very relevant and extremely purposeful. The artist wishes to leave us with a wonderful feeling by making us question our importance not only to ourselves but also to the world at large! 


What We Need & What You Get

  • I need funding of around 3000 USD for exhibiting at the India Art Festival.
  • All these funds shall be utilized to acquire a stall at this Art Fair and in the corresponding marketing activities.
  • The contributors shall receive interesting perks from my side which would be my previous artworks, miniature artworks, thank you emails and more.

The Impact

  • This is my endeavour to make people realize how everyone's existence in this world is important. This travelling installation pathway helps people improve their morale and increase their self valuation. It instills a unsaid confidence in them to define themselves and make a mark on this world.
  • The exhibition which was held last month also had a huge impact on the viewers and all the visitors went back with an extremely fulfilled experience.

Other Ways You Can Help

You guys can help us in other ways as well. You can share this campaign on your social networks and help me spread the value of self-realization and hence help this minimalist installation pathway travel globally.

story:

My name is Raul Tumba. My project is pass five digital artwork to the silkscreen format. The four images have to remake to six or eight colors to achieve better results. 

I would need the support of all of you to buy materials to make five screenprints.


...........................................................................................................


RAUL TUMBA _Digital artist

Work in film and television advertising making : Concept art, digital painting, 3D modeler, texture and animator.

This is my personal page

story:
The ReVisions Story

Students from Orr Community Academy are creating mosaic letters, chairs and tables to start a micro-lending fund for social enterprise projects of the students.

Students have been working hard, learninig mosaic work and planning their social enterprise businesses.

Your contribution can: 

- create jobs and small businesses for high school students

- allow students to have the financial resources needed to attend college

WE NEED $5000 TO MAKE THIS HAPPEN! 

You will receive one of several of these original works of art depending on your level of giving

For a $10 donation you will get a personalized Thank You note from the ReVisions students.

For a $20 donation you will get a 12 X 18 mosaic letter

For a $50 donation you will get a hand painted chair

For $75 donation you will get a mosaic seat chair

For $100 donation you will get a small mosaic top table

For $150 donation you will get a large mosaic top table

For a $300 contribution a very special contributor  will get a mosaic garden bench

AND , OF COURSE, GET THIS OUT TO YOUR FRIENDS AND FAMILY SO THEY CAN CONTRIBUTE TOO.

story:
Short Summary

 

A beautiful work of art (Oil Painting of two horse heads been donated to Whisper Poetry to raise funds. A donation of R 50.00 gives you a chance to win it.

What We Need & What You Get

We need you to donate R 50.00 to stand a chance to win this beautiful work of art.

We also contribute R 500.00 towards a frame for the piece of art


The Impact

Whisper Poetry is a Family Friendly Club coaching children to write poetry and each year we publish a book of verse and release a video of the Art and Photography received from entrants. We have NO sponsor and do all our own fund raising.

Your support will make it possible for our very poor children to get exposure for their writing (Poems and Short Stories),Art, Music and photography.

Our reputation at schools over the past 11 years will show that we are a Club that delivers and that we are there for our students and members

Risks & Challenges

 Your donation of R 50.00($5.00) is the risk BUT we commit to advising ever donor of who has won this beautiful painting

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Besides purchasing a ticket for yourself you can assist us by selling tickets for us and earn a 10% commission for each ticket sold (That is R 5.00 - $0.50)is yours for each ticket you sell)

story:
Hello and welcome to our Indiegogo page. We are a group of students and recent graduates from the Art and Art History program at the University of Toronto Mississauga in collaboration with Sheridan College. Our fourth year painting class has organized a show at a gallery in Toronto this coming June and are seeking support in funding this wonderful opportunity. With your support we will be receiving valuable exposure and initiation into the Toronto art community and a successful start to our artistic careers. If you are interested in supporting emerging Canadian artists and the contemporary arts scene in the GTA please consider contributing to our project and sharing it with others.


A Note on Perks: 6 x 9 inch paintings are to be picked up at the show opening June 1 (details TBA) or delivered personally by one of the artists. If you have donated $35 or more but live outside of the Greater Toronto Area please email a shipping address to a.harmata@live.com. Thank you for your support!

Event Info:
https://www.facebook.com/events/801748373273285/

story:
This project is the graduation exhibition of a young art student who believes in using art to question and critique the world around her. I am a student at Bezalel Academy of Art in Jerusalem, and my exhibition aims to inspire dialogue about the reality in which I live, and take a different approach to investigating and engaging in the conflict.

In my work, I revisit the course travelled by the Palmach (part of the Jewish fighting force) in the 1948 battle for Jerusalem. As a result of the war, the state of Israel was established and many of the Palestinian villages in the area were depopulated and wiped off the map. Using the testimony of a Palmach commander, which provides me with an outline of the pre-1948 map, I attempt to locate these villages, or what remains of them. In doing so, I try to question the notion of memory as a container of facts, and instead, to investigate it as a changing construct. Ultimately, my project is about creating a new memory.

Through drawing on walls, spray-painting abandoned houses, numbering rubble, organizing objects in once lived-in spaces, and photographing all of these acts, I attempt to turn invisible spaces into existent spaces. My work raises questions about these places and their part in history, and explores the role that photography can play in fashioning memory and history.

Arranging a large scale exhibition requires a lot of resources. I need to purchase photographic materials, chemicals for emulsion, and paper for printing, print the pictures and catalog, frame the works, prepare the exhibition space and promote the event. I also hope to be able to take my exhibition to places outside of Israel, increasing awareness about the conflict and the injustices occurring in its name, and using my art to ignite discussion in communities around the world.

The funds raised in this campaign will enable me to complete my exhibition, and will specifically cover my printing and framing expenses.

Any funds raised beyond my target goal will go towards helping me carry out the necessary steps in order to bring my exhibition to audiences around the world.

I hope you will help me produce my exhibition. Any amount of support that you can give will help me reach my goals.

story:
Ruins and abandonded structures

I always had a strong curiosity about ruins and architectural remains. That's no wonder, as Berlin in the late 1960s was a place where you could easily spot the scars and empty sites, resulting from WWII. Yet as a child, we crawled through bunkers and ruins, collected cartridges, rusted helmets and handguns, drilled bullets and shell splinters out of walls and tried to sense the smell of history and what had happened in these places, when they were still inhabited and animated.
Decades later, when the Berlin wall came down, this curiosity hadn’t subsided and I strolled through countless barracks and Plattenbauten which had been recently abandoned. Unfortunately, I didn’t photograph at that time, but the pictures stayed in my head.

It took more than another decade, when a friend took me for a visit to Wünsdorf, a vast military area from the time of WWI, which had been the headquarters of the Red Army in Western Europe. As a kid who grew up in times of the Cold War, this was quite fascinating to see and it really propelled the imagination. What I saw there led to the strong impulse to take out the camera and capture the locations. As usual with my sense of exaggeration, this led to consequently discovering all related remains of historic impact around Berlin. The then mostly forgotten Olympic Village from 1936, military airfields, barracks, forgotten sanatoriums and even the listening post atop Teufelsberg

 

 

Four-legged survivors

The next years I was chasing around, looking for abandoned structures - preferably of historic interest - which contained a space that would have an impact on me. I mostly found these in abandoned sanatoriums and theatre halls where I could easily sense the “Genius Loci”.

When I visited an abandoned power plant from the early 30s, I unexpectedly came across a single yellow chair, just standing there, like a last sign of previous life, which could give future archaeologists a hint of the former inhabitants. Somehow this chair helped me inhabit and structure the space to not get totally lost - in space and mind. And from then on I was determined to find a chair everywhere I went. Strangely enough, even if structures had been completely stripped off, you could always find a chair - nothing else, but chairs remained.

 

 

Object of desire

Important to me was the rediscovery of Lacan’s theorem of the “Object small a”, which made me realize, that these chairs were the substitute for my “unattainable object of desire” and symbolized my fear of photographing real, living people, as much as the ruins stood for my own life at that time. It then became clear to me what drove me, and I knew I needed to get out of this, but still kept pursuing this project like a maniac. I felt I had to ride it out to the end, and finally did.

When I came across the term Sede Vacante (vacant seat / vacant site), which  signifies the interim period after a pope has died and his successor is in charge, I was instantly struck with the multiple meaning of it. Even more, as it fuelled my predilection for wordplay.

Now, a couple of years later there only remains the need to make a book which bends the chaos left by the past into something meaningful, the final statement in a working process. And because of this, I regard this work rather as a depiction of a state of mind, than an exact mapping of historical sites. And that's precisely the point, that distinguishes this project from others dealing with abandoned places.

 

 

The project

Some months ago, I was approached by Rob van Hoesel, the noted designer and co-founder of The Eriskay Connection, an independent publishing house in the Netherlands, asking why these pictures hadn't been published yet. I replied, who should dare to publish this series? and he answered dryly: me. I couldn't but take this for a hoax at first, but very soon I had to realize, that he was serious about it and  confident of my work. In the following weeks, we had a close and perfectly smooth cooperation on developing the basics of this publication and all of a sudden we are here, with a perfected project, a practicable business plan, secured worldwide distribution and a printer at the ready.

 

 

What you get from us

A meticulously crafted book, featuring a unique design and containing exceptional photographs which, at the first presentation, were compared in quality to the works of Robert Polidori. All this executed to the highest standards and without compromises. We not only know what we're doing, we love our work. And we're convinced, you'll love it too!

 

What we need from you

It is common knowledge, that publishing a book is neither an easy, nor a cheap task. That's where we have to rely on your support. The production costs for this rather elaborate production total at app. 13.000€, part of which we are able to procure ourselves. For the rest of at least 8.000€, we decided to rely on your interest and support and launch this campaign.
We are sincerely optimistic and we cherish any contribution, no matter how big or small, as an appreciation to our project and as an encouragement to carry on. Thank you in advance!

 

The plan

Our actual plan is to have the printing finished in time to officially present the book in Amsterdam, at this years Unseen Photo Fair - from September 26th - 29th - where we would love to meet you at the Eriskay stall.

In parallel, Sede Vacante will be competing for the Paris Photo photobook awards and hopefully will also be presented at this years Offprint Paris, from November 14th - 17th. Of course, you are cordially invited to pay Eriskay a visit there.

 

 

The book

Please bear with me for having been a bit epic, thereby I had nearly forgotten the important facts:

  • Format: 230 x 310 mm
  • Pages: 80 (40 pages with fold-outs)
  • Illustrations: 18
  • Language: English 
  • Paper inside: Lessebo Design Smooth 1.2 White 150 gr
  • Print: offset printing full color
  • Cover: 8 page cover 
  • Typeface: Beton
  • Cover material: Brillianta 4099 Cloth cached on Butterfly Black 300 gr
  • Cover print: black foil print on front, back and spine
  • Binding: Swiss binding with black cloth finish
  • Edition: 730 copies + a special edition of 20 (+5 AP)

 

Those involved

David Kregenow is an accomplished architectural photographer and an alumni of Folkwang School. His preference for living life on an oblique course, has led him straight through the southern countries of Europe and meanwhile back to his hometown of Berlin. During the last years he gained notoriety by portraying fellow photographers.

Rob van Hoesel is a noted dutch designer and co-founder of The Eriskay Connection, a dedicated independent publishing house, specialising in books on art, visual culture, architecture and photography.
story_txt:
Ruins and abandonded structures 
I always had a strong curiosity about ruins and architectural remains. That's no wonder, as Berlin in the late 1960s was a place where you could easily spot the scars and empty sites, resulting from WWII. Yet as a child, we crawled through bunkers and ruins, collected cartridges, rusted helmets and handguns, drilled bullets and shell splinters out of walls and tried to sense the smell of history and what had happened in these places, when they were still inhabited and animated. Decades later, when the Berlin wall came down, this curiosity hadn’t subsided and I strolled through countless barracks and Plattenbauten which had been recently abandoned. Unfortunately, I didn’t photograph at that time, but the pictures stayed in my head. 
It took more than another decade, when a friend took me for a visit to Wünsdorf, a vast military area from the time of WWI, which had been the headquarters of the Red Army in Western Europe. As a kid who grew up in times of the Cold War, this was quite fascinating to see and it really propelled the imagination. What I saw there led to the strong impulse to take out the camera and capture the locations. As usual with my sense of exaggeration, this led to consequently discovering all related remains of historic impact around Berlin. The then mostly forgotten Olympic Village from 1936, military airfields, barracks, forgotten sanatoriums and even the listening post atop Teufelsberg
 

 
Four-legged survivors 
The next years I was chasing around, looking for abandoned structures - preferably of historic interest - which contained a space that would have an impact on me. I mostly found these in abandoned sanatoriums and theatre halls where I could easily sense the “Genius Loci”. 
When I visited an abandoned power plant from the early 30s, I unexpectedly came across a single yellow chair, just standing there, like a last sign of previous life, which could give future archaeologists a hint of the former inhabitants. Somehow this chair helped me inhabit and structure the space to not get totally lost - in space and mind. And from then on I was determined to find a chair everywhere I went. Strangely enough, even if structures had been completely stripped off, you could always find a chair - nothing else, but chairs remained.
 

 
Object of desire
Important to me was the rediscovery of Lacan’s theorem of the “Object small a”, which made me realize, that these chairs were the substitute for my “unattainable object of desire” and symbolized my fear of photographing real, living people, as much as the ruins stood for my own life at that time. It then became clear to me what drove me, and I knew I needed to get out of this, but still kept pursuing this project like a maniac. I felt I had to ride it out to the end, and finally did.
When I came across the term Sede Vacante (vacant seat / vacant site), which  signifies the interim period after a pope has died and his successor is in charge, I was instantly struck with the multiple meaning of it. Even more, as it fuelled my predilection for wordplay.
Now, a couple of years later there only remains the need to make a book which bends the chaos left by the past into something meaningful, the final statement in a working process. And because of this, I regard this work rather as a depiction of a state of mind, than an exact mapping of historical sites. And that's precisely the point, that distinguishes this project from others dealing with abandoned places.
 

 
The project
Some months ago, I was approached by Rob van Hoesel, the noted designer and co-founder of The Eriskay Connection, an independent publishing house in the Netherlands, asking why these pictures hadn't been published yet. I replied, who should dare to publish this series? and he answered dryly: me. I couldn't but take this for a hoax at first, but very soon I had to realize, that he was serious about it and  confident of my work. In the following weeks, we had a close and perfectly smooth cooperation on developing the basics of this publication and all of a sudden we are here, with a perfected project, a practicable business plan, secured worldwide distribution and a printer at the ready.
 


 
What you get from us
A meticulously crafted book, featuring a unique design and containing exceptional photographs which, at the first presentation, were compared in quality to the works of Robert Polidori. All this executed to the highest standards and without compromises. We not only know what we're doing, we love our work. And we're convinced, you'll love it too!
 
What we need from you
It is common knowledge, that publishing a book is neither an easy, nor a cheap task. That's where we have to rely on your support. The production costs for this rather elaborate production total at app. 13.000€, part of which we are able to procure ourselves. For the rest of at least 8.000€, we decided to rely on your interest and support and launch this campaign.We are sincerely optimistic and we cherish any contribution, no matter how big or small, as an appreciation to our project and as an encouragement to carry on. Thank you in advance!
 
The plan
Our actual plan is to have the printing finished in time to officially present the book in Amsterdam, at this years Unseen Photo Fair - from September 26th - 29th - where we would love to meet you at the Eriskay stall.
In parallel, Sede Vacante will be competing for the Paris Photo photobook awards and hopefully will also be presented at this years Offprint Paris, from November 14th - 17th. Of course, you are cordially invited to pay Eriskay a visit there.
 

 
The book
Please bear with me for having been a bit epic, thereby I had nearly forgotten the important facts:

Format: 230 x 310 mm
Pages: 80 (40 pages with fold-outs)
Illustrations: 18
Language: English 
Paper inside: Lessebo Design Smooth 1.2 White 150 gr
Print: offset printing full color
Cover: 8 page cover 
Typeface: Beton
Cover material: Brillianta 4099 Cloth cached on Butterfly Black 300 gr
Cover print: black foil print on front, back and spine
Binding: Swiss binding with black cloth finish
Edition: 730 copies + a special edition of 20 (+5 AP)

 
Those involved
David Kregenow is an accomplished architectural photographer and an alumni of Folkwang School. His preference for living life on an oblique course, has led him straight through the southern countries of Europe and meanwhile back to his hometown of Berlin. During the last years he gained notoriety by portraying fellow photographers.
Rob van Hoesel is a noted dutch designer and co-founder of The Eriskay Connection, a dedicated independent publishing house, specialising in books on art, visual culture, architecture and photography.

story:
The Entrepreneurship Center needs a mural.

My name is Noah Salem, I am filmmaker, entrepreneur, and student at the Met High School.  I am the proud founder of Kick-Vids, a crowdfunding video service, that creates campaigns to help entrepreneurs and artists secure funding.

We need $1,000 to paint a mural.

The MET High School has one art program: it is small and underfunded.  Currently, volunteer Raffaello LaMantia and his fifteen students, are seeking to raise $1,000 to create a mural on the wall of the Met's Center for Innovation and Entrepreneurship (E-Center).

Why this matters.

The Met's E-Center is a place of creativity and energy; all we enter are encouraged to take risks, work-hard, and be creative.  A student designed and painted mural who extend a welcoming invitation to stop talking and start making! 

We appreciate all support.

Every little bit helps.  Whether you want to donate $5 or $50 this project deserves your attention, your time, and your donation.  Granting these fifteen students a platform to display their work may just serve as the moment a student transforms into an artist.

story:
A project by: The Bohemian Team

Period: 25-27 July 2014

Location: Brasov Historic Center, Transylvania(RO)


Who are we?

We're an enthusiastic group of artists and creative people eager to continue the tradition of our annual festival for our city, that will attract good people from the whole country and abroad.

The initiative sparked out from two sister's minds, Szidonia (porcelain painter) and Orsolya (photographer), but by now our laboratory of curly ideas grew quite bigger.

Our team is involved in various creative projects, among others volunteering at film festivals, making animation and documentary movies, contributing in organizing other festivals, exhibitions, creating artistic installations for music festivals, mural painting, etc.


Our festival!

'Bohemian Square' is a cultural-artistic event that offers a colorful variety of creative activities for the whole community.

The purpose of the project is first of all to reflect on the concept of public space in the contemporary culture, the development of citizens’ responsibility for these spaces, as well as stimulating their initiative to take part in the positive reinvention of their urban surroundings.

The event's goal is also to support artists, musicians and performers and to offer them the possibility to promote their work.

We are happy to be heading towards the second edition this year, when the festival enriches its offer, focusing on its feature as an artistic platform. We already have more than 50 artisans from the whole country for the Central Square exhibiton, 20 workshop leaders, around 15 musicians, 10 architects, 10 visual artists, libraries and museums. They will all perform and present interesting programs and exhibitions for 3 days.

The participants all came with fresh and unusual solutions in order to reinvent the 3 main locations of the festival and create in the public environment a common place for communication and interaction in the public environment.


Be part of it!

Your generous donations contribute in bringing to life an event that tries to raise awareness against consumerism - encouraging people to focus on each other.

Our funding goal of 3000 euros will cover only part of the festival expenses, however, your contribution makes a big difference and enables us to put our ideas into practice.

As you can see in our presentation-film, we will use your donations for the following purposes:

  • support for the performing musicians, artists and architects(transport to the festivals location, accomodation costs and financial compensation for the performances)
  • the material needed for the various artistic installations and set-ups
  • the materials for the workshops and contests
  • the material necessary for a good advertising campaign to ensure a good promotion and publicity for the event

We will reward your contribution with colorfully named Perks: among others we will mention your name on the event's page, we give away limited edition stickers, tote-bags and t-shirts with the festival's print on them, unique art-work created at the festival and you can even be a VIP guest at Bohemian Square.


The Impact

The beneficiaries of this event are the entire Brasov community, visitors from the country and all the tourists who practically flood Brasov during summer. We expect an audience of approx. 7000 people.

All activities on our program are for free. Visitors can enjoy concerts, workshops, contests, performances, screenings etc. without paying anything. We are prepairing a colorful palette of activities, in which everybody will be able to find something interesting to suit them.

Our region needs an event like this. It will changes people's perception from being simple visitors of an event to becoming an active part in it. With our festival we wish to promote local and international artists, creative people and to encourage people to get in touch with them; to communicate and play together.

As we're presenting a few foreign artists at the festival as well, we want to underline that interaction through art and culture can be a common language for everybody.


Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help us spread the word!

  • Share  OUR CAMPAIGN LINK  on your Facebook Page! Help us get the news spread by using social media and word of mouth - make some noise about our campaign :) You can use sharing tools on Indiegogo.
  • Share our Facebook page with your friends
  • Change your profile picture to the logo of Bohemian Square to help spread the word


The Bohemian Square Staff:  Szidonia, Orsolya, Ioana, Ana Maria, Carmen, Ioana, Alina, Tudor, Klaus - warmly thank you in advance - we appreciate your interest and care !!! :)
