story:
About Young but Capable

Young but Capable Project is an art and writing anthology featuring seventeen artists and seven writers. On the administrative team we have two artists, a writer, and a beta reader. The project is organized by American Kestrel, who is running this campaign. The team has been working on this project since September 2019 and, in addition to the book, would like to offer additional stickers, prints, and charms to this project.

So what makes Young but Capable different and worth supporting? 

Our core mission is lifting up young, often overlooked, creative talent. It’s about saying that years of experience aren’t everything. It’s about acknowledging the amount of respect that the dedication and enthusiasm of young adults deserves. 

The contributing creatives to this project include:  American Kestrel - @BellaRaeAnne - Aideryn - Andy @Prookal - Ara @MsArachnid - ArbaughArt - Ariasune - Dragon - Ela @The13thCanvas - H.E. Palm @ Hille13920_luck - Juju @jujuoh - Kathryn @therealstaples - Len - Max - Meridith @mystical-flute - Pistol Star - @prrtnrr - Danielle @raspberrylimerichie - Ruby @chaosstardust - Sally Vintner - Sarah Holden - Seppo - Echo Reinert @skeletalecho - Skyler Crossman - Vani @tuesdayinthedas - Vee

The merchandise shown in the images are, as stated, for reference. Final merch images will be shown in updates. The merch artists of this project include:  @BellaRaeAnne - Aideryn - Len - Max - Pistol Star - Sarah Holden - Echo Reinert @skeletalecho - Vani @tuesdayinthedas

The following artists and writers are also available for commission work and their rates are linked here:  @BellaRaeAnne - @prrtnrr - Kathryn @therealstaples - Vee

 

What We Need & What You Get

Crowdfunding this project should provide us with enough to meet our three primary objectives: paying our contributing creatives, offset production costs, and donate a little bit to charities around the world. Our goal has been set at $3,000 which will help cover the following expenses:

Paying our contributors. There are 26 people behind the creation of this project. Around 34% of funding costs go to them, if we meet our goal. If we surpass our goal, 50% of the excess funds also go to them.

Fulfillment of perks: From sampling to printing and ordering merchandise, more than half of the initial expenses fit into this category. This also includes Indiegogo fees and transaction fees. 

Charity funds: 5%, or around $150, of our initial funding goal goes to support three amazing causes. These causes are the Polaris Project, Cystic Fibrosis Canada, and a Fire Relief Fund for First Nations in Australia. If we surpass our goal, 50% of excess funds will go to these causes.

 

The Impact

So what happens if this anthology is a success? You get some really wonderful creative work and support some important global causes! This project will also help boost visibility for these creative people and let other young artists and writers be inspired.

 

Risks & Challenges

If we succeed in our funding goal before the midpoint of the campaign, stretch goals will be made available. Those will feature in an update.

As stated above, this an all-or-nothing or fixed funding campaign; if we don’t raise the full amount or more, you get refunded and none of the physical perks will be printed or made. We will update backers on our plans, if that ends up being the case.

We have a wide pool of contributors due to our focus on giving fresh voices a place to be heard. It's a risk that not all of them might deliver the content expected. You'll still get some excellent pieces.

In any project like this, the printer is an important factor. We plan to use established vendors with a reputation for delivering, and will make sure to look into outcomes before placing the order. American Kestrel has experience in this domain, and is excited to look at their outcomes.

We have also received samples from several sticker and acrylic charm producing vendors. This gives us the opportunity to do quality assurance on their end product, meaning the risk is not whether they can deliver, but whether they can do so in a timely manner. Much like the printers, part of this will be out of our hands once the order is put in, but we've done the best job we can do as far as selecting them.

For an international project, the question of international shipping comes up. While we've priced things to reflect the shipping prices as they are now, there's always a chance those prices might change. We've built in a margin we believe is large enough to cover things even in the event of an unexpected increase.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot contribute at this time, we would all appreciate it if you shared our project. You can also find us on twitter @youngbutcapable and on tumblr @youngbutcapableproject.
story_txt:
About Young but Capable
Young but Capable Project is an art and writing anthology featuring seventeen artists and seven writers. On the administrative team we have two artists, a writer, and a beta reader. The project is organized by American Kestrel, who is running this campaign. The team has been working on this project since September 2019 and, in addition to the book, would like to offer additional stickers, prints, and charms to this project.
So what makes Young but Capable different and worth supporting? 
Our core mission is lifting up young, often overlooked, creative talent. It’s about saying that years of experience aren’t everything. It’s about acknowledging the amount of respect that the dedication and enthusiasm of young adults deserves. 
The contributing creatives to this project include:  American Kestrel - @BellaRaeAnne - Aideryn - Andy @Prookal - Ara @MsArachnid - ArbaughArt - Ariasune - Dragon - Ela @The13thCanvas - H.E. Palm @ Hille13920_luck - Juju @jujuoh - Kathryn @therealstaples - Len - Max - Meridith @mystical-flute - Pistol Star - @prrtnrr - Danielle @raspberrylimerichie - Ruby @chaosstardust - Sally Vintner - Sarah Holden  - Seppo - Echo Reinert @skeletalecho - Skyler Crossman - Vani @tuesdayinthedas - Vee
The merchandise shown in the images are, as stated, for reference. Final merch images will be shown in updates. The merch artists of this project include:  @BellaRaeAnne - Aideryn - Len - Max - Pistol Star - Sarah Holden - Echo Reinert @skeletalecho - Vani @tuesdayinthedas

story:
Hi, I'm Jason Kochis. I'm an artist, designer, and musician based in Atlanta, GA. My love of art and music collided in 2002 when I started designing gigposters.


Over the past 18 years, I've had the honor of creating over 350 gigposters for the bands Superdrag, Dinosaur Jr., Nada Surf, Letters To Cleo, Ozma, The Rentals, El Scorcho, Daniel Miller, Hyperspace, The Descendents, Guided By Voices, and many more.


Being in quarantine inspired me to self-publish a 132 page book that collects all of my poster designs to date. I thought this would be a fun way to celebrate a time when we could go see super awesome shows and without having to worry about a global pandemic.


With this campaign, I'm asking for your support to help offset the cost of printing the books and have plenty of cool incentives in return for your donations. Some of the designs in this book will be printed and published in color for the first time. John Davis, the lead singer of Superdrag and The Lees of Memory has even provided the intro to the book reflecting on how gigposters help fans commemorate the time they had at the show.


Rocking Rewards Include the Following:

· Exclusive Rock Soldier stickers and buttons.

· A downloadable e-book version of the book.

· Having your name printed and featured in the book.

· Rock Soldier t-shirts and hats

· Printed versions of the book are available in softcover and hardcover.

· Several rare, one-of-a-kind artist proofs of sold out Superdrag posters.

 
Once the campaign is complete, all rewards will ship by December 2020. Shipping times may vary due to COVID-19.


Can’t contribute, don't worry! You can still help me by sharing this page and getting the word out. I really appreciate you checking out my campaign and helping me reach my goal.

Stay safe and Rock On!

Jason

story:
THE EXHIBITION

Place, travel and environment play an important part in the fiber artist Maria-Theresa Fernandes’ internationally acclaimed work. Throughout her career, travel has given her the opportunity to reflect and create works relating to the surroundings of the countries she experienced. History and poetry are brilliantly woven into the fabric of Fernandes’ works, which translate her physical and emotional attachment to the lands she visited. 

ARTIST STATEMENT

Travel has been the main source of inspiration and has influenced the direction of my work over the years. Some countries, it's people and the landscape have contributed to the imagery, concepts in my work. The investigation of new materials and technology has allowed for experimentation. While earlier works showed the use of paint and stitchery as mark making, recent work has involved the density of population in East London and it's rich cultural diversity. Place and living in the surroundings is an important element in my work. The physical and emotional aspect of feeling and experiencing rather than an artificial portrayal of the environment. Density of surface using layering of material to create a dimensional effect related to the density of population. Some work was also politically related e.g. The Wait 2009, "Exclusion" 2006. These works were created as a result of living in E.London where over 200 languages are spoken. Technical skills often using traditional application is combined with new technology. I often take workshops in order to improve my skills and this allows for another way of thinking and working. The business and commercial area of London has recently inspired the new body of work. Handmade felting using translucent material is combined with digital photography and printing to create works that relate to the new development of this area which has recently been bought by the Chinese for business purposes. The relocation back to Baltimore after 12 years is exciting. Baltimore has a large Art Community and the abandoned buildings have some amazing art. I would like to work on a project showing the contrasts of 2 cities one that has a smaller diverse community, the other, a Major World City that is large and has the most diverse Group of people living there.

ARTIST BACKGROUND

Born in Kenya, Fernandes studied in London and Manchester, England. She received her B.A. (Hons) degree in Textiles with a specialty in Embroidery. The United Kingdom is the only country to confer this degree. A graduate from Cranbrook Academy of Art in Detroit with a MFA in Fiber Art, Maria-Theresa Fernandes has participated in over 25 solo exhibitions and several international exhibitions. This global artist is the recipient of prestigious international grants and awards and such as the Pollock-Krasner Foundation grant, the Ruth Cheven Foundation award, and the UNESCO –Arts International award.

story:
Short Summary

  • This sculpture concept has been chosen for placement at the Cedar Park Town Center Sculpture Garden along with 11 other artists and their art. Looking For A Hero is the sole creation of Lancelot Smith and will start production in mid August.

    Sculptor, Writer/ Filmmaker. Lancelot Smith was born in Santa Monica, CA. He graduated from The London Film School in 1995 and is currently attending Art Institute of Austin for his second degree program in Game Art and Design. Previous art projects were memorials like Sembazuru;

    https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=184089311614167&set=pb.100000392991123.-2207520000.1405783373.&type=3&theater, 

    A memorial of a large scale 45 foot high origami crane which he engineered and designed with Daniel Skirblah and built with a host of talented crew members. The memorial gave people a place to grieve the loss of loved ones at the annual Burning man event. The project culminated in a large pyre at the end of a week symbolizing the empermanance of art and a final farewell.  

    Lancelot lives in Cedar Park Town Center, with his wife, son and two dogs and furthers his quest to create art for the community.

  • Lancelot: "As a pet guardian and adopter myself I see the importance of making decisions that can have a more profound effect on the world. Many pets need a hero and the sculpture "Looking For A Hero" is to remind us all that the decision that we are capable of making can have a profound effect on not only the unwanted animals lives but our own.
  • "Looking For a Hero" draws a person in,  to search for the story of the two very different dogs brought together by its artist. One is a Collie and one is Mut of sorts. Both could be found in any shelter and need a hero to let them out as they look longingly and hopeful for a sign of release. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need one 4x 8 - 1/2 inch to 3/4 inch steel plate, some grinding tools, gloves, misc. materials and transportation expences.
  • Contributors  will receive an honorable mention on the upcoming website and or a signed limited edition print of artists rendering of the sculpture.
  • All funds will go to only the project and its expense and accounted for. If additional funds are raised there will be a second piece made for CPTC to be placed wherever the community wants it within the Cedar Park Town Center development.

The Impact

  • Supporting a local artist and locally made art.
  • Art with purpose and a story.
  • Tangible and community oriented. 

Risks & Challenges

All art is a challenge. Its what we live for. 

  • A supportive community in the arts is paramount to a civilized culture.
  • Gathering the community to be a part of its own unique self expression.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about the Looking For A Hero  campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Like us on Facebook ; 
Lancelot Smith's Art For Cedar Park, TX

story:
The Gallery of Dreams, the brainchild of NobodobodoN Mystiek, is a temporal art experience - the art inside can only be experienced during the short time that the gallery exists. None of the art will have been photographed or displayed prior to the event, and it will all be destroyed along with the gallery at the culmination of the event.
 
This project will serve to remind participants that there is only now. No photography will be allowed in the Gallery, though we encourage people to create and leave additional art in the gallery during its brief run.

We seek to supplement the grant we received from Art Garden. With your help, we can make the project even more spectacular!

NobodobodoN and Izzi B are veterans of this art-making thing, having been involved in sundry past projects, including 99 Bottles of Beer, Boot in a Dryer Acoustic Techno, the Dinky Box, Cathartica, Orobouros (fangs!), and more.

All donors will receive recognition on the donor's wall, along with other perks.

Other Ways You Can Help

Create art for the Gallery! Email Nobody@nobodobodon.com or retsparrow@gmail.com for details.
If you are at Flipside, sign up for a docent shift (or three!)
Share information about this campaign with your friends!

Visit us on facebook at https://www.facebook.com/pages/Gallery-of-Dreams-at-Flipside/180939145345436

story:
Our Story

 Live It, Breathe It comes as the idea-child of Titilayo Derricotte, graduate of Newark, NJ's performing Arts High School and is a recent graduate of New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts. The goal of this evening-length performance is to showcase artistic talent ranging from dance, drama, and vocal to instrumental and visual arts. In addition, Live It, Breathe It seeks to provide an atmosphere for Newark’s talent and beyond to perform their crafts, and to immerse themselves in that which creatively gives them life and breath. Live It, Breathe It is a vehicle with many goals. We aim to instill a sense of value and purpose in the Newark arts community, create a movement among young professionals that will sustain and garner positive attention in the media, bridge gaps between artists, establish a sense of kinship, and engage the next wave of artists to aspire and achieve their dreams.

 

The Impact

In addition to being held at historical Newark Symphony Hall, a performance venue that has housed such great performers as James Brown, the Rolling Stones, Judy Garland, Sarah Vaughn and more, Live It, Breathe It aims to give voice to a new generation of artists. Further, it endeavors to present artists who are dedicated to their art form and wish to bring the fruits of their labor to a platform where the quietly thriving creative community of Newark, NJ can be seen in a positive light.  Ultimately Live It, Breathe It seeks to bring hope and higher aspirations to succeeding artistic generations.  What better way to accomplish this goal than provide the example ourselves?

 

What We Need, What You Get

The Live It, Breathe It campaign will begin on June 26, 2011 and end on October 10, 2011.  The performance is se to launch October 29, 2011 but we need funding now.  We want to make this event one that will go beyond a good night at the theatre to penetrate the consciousness of audience members.  We don't just want patrons to leave having seen an evening of excellent performances.  We want them to leave with a sense that this is something that can truly change the way Newark is viewed by the public, and that will inspire younger generations to become involved with the arts.  All monies will go to the Live It, Breathe It campaign which includes the Black Box theatre at Newark Symphony Hall, reception activities, and personal 'thank you, patron' gift bags to show our appreciation for supporting this incredible endeavor!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please send the link for the Live It, Breathe It campaign to all those who may be interested, and thank you for supporting our dreams!

 

Committee Members

Titilayo Derricotte- Founder and Artistic Director

Ali Derricotte- Graphic designer

Levell Hawkins- Music coordinator

Tariq Moody- Fashion liaison and Master of Ceremonies

Muyiwa Omisore- Public Relations liaison and Assistant Project Manager

Cali Spaulding- Project treasurer

story:
Hey. Who the hell are you?

Oh... hey there... um... I'm Griffin. I draw for a living. Just go to my website and see. It's ShadedAreas.com.

Oh neat! So... what's all this then? A Nerdy Sexy Pinup Calendar?

My tastefully sexy pinups of fictional icons have brought me a touch of positive notiriaty. I get lot of requests and a calendar is one of them. I think it's time to make it happen!

It's a great way to package up a collection of art that can be easily shared and shown. I'd be happy. You'd be happy. Future nerdy folks besides us would be happy. Everyone would win!

Neat! So... why haven't you done it yourself?

Two reasons. Other paid commissions always get to cut in line and the cost of printing quality calendars is a little tough.

So what's this "Limited Edition" stuff? Sounds like you're making a bunch of these.

Oh! The campaign backers get an exclusive version of it. They will include ALL the pinups plus added materials. Then the calendars for public sale will include only the pinups.

Exclusive content is important with these things, IMHO.

Sounds like you put a lot of thought into this. Why a campaign though?

I think people would be excited about, but you can never be certain. This way I know people want it before I break my wrist trying to get it done. 

Also, this makes certain that other paid work can't cut in line. This won't be a personal project if it's backed.

I'm kind of psyched about this if you can't tell. :-)

That's cool! Okay... well if I don't have the cash to put into this yet...  how can I help until then!?

Go "like" the facebook page for this project and tell your friends about it.
https://www.facebook.com/NerdySexyPinupCalendar

IndieGoGo also has it's own wonderfully convenient sharing tools if you want to just plug the campaign without liking a page and following all the chatter and progress reports that will come up.

You can count on me! I can't wait to see this done!

Thank you so much! I won't dissapoint.

Hey. Who the hell are you?
Oh... hey there... um... I'm Griffin. I draw for a living. Just go to my website and see. It's ShadedAreas.com.
Oh neat! So... what's all this then? A Nerdy Sexy Pinup Calendar?
My tastefully sexy pinups of fictional icons have brought me a touch of positive notiriaty. I get lot of requests and a calendar is one of them. I think it's time to make it happen!It's a great way to package up a collection of art that can be easily shared and shown. I'd be happy. You'd be happy. Future nerdy folks besides us would be happy. Everyone would win!


Neat! So... why haven't you done it yourself?
Two reasons. Other paid commissions always get to cut in line and the cost of printing quality calendars is a little tough.
So what's this "Limited Edition" stuff? Sounds like you're making a bunch of these.
Oh! The campaign backers get an exclusive version of it. They will include ALL the pinups plus added materials. Then the calendars for public sale will include only the pinups.
Exclusive content is important with these things, IMHO.
Sounds like you put a lot of thought into this. Why a campaign though?


I think people would be excited about, but you can never be certain. This way I know people want it before I break my wrist trying to get it done. Also, this makes certain that other paid work can't cut in line. This won't be a personal project if it's backed.I'm kind of psyched about this if you can't tell. :-)


That's cool! Okay... well if I don't have the cash to put into this yet...  how can I help until then!?
Go "like" the facebook page for this project and tell your friends about it.https://www.facebook.com/NerdySexyPinupCalendarIndieGoGo also has it's own wonderfully convenient sharing tools if you want to just plug the campaign without liking a page and following all the chatter and progress reports that will come up.

You can count on me! I can't wait to see this done!
Thank you so much! I won't dissapoint.

story:
A huge door has opened for me that can help me become an international artist! ... and possibly get a Gary Smith Portait in Pastel too!

I am an artist who drawings and paints figures, portraits, urban scenes and murals.

I have been invited to compete at the Louvre (under the Crystal) in Figure Drawing. This event also includes displaying large artwork there.

The Impact:

This can lead to my being able to sell my paintings in other countries which is a HUGE jump in any artist's career. 

ALREADY a Fine Art Auction House in China has let me know they are interested in representing me if I do well.  ... so it i up to me now that this door is open.

What I need:

I have managed to save the money for the French Art Symposium ($2600) and the flight but am short for such costs as boxing and shipping large artwork BY ONLY $1800.

What you get:

If you can champion me for some amount and send me your email, I will send you photos and possibly a video of the event when I return.

Furthermore if you sponsor me for $300 and send a photo of your family member or pet I will gladly draw him/her in soft pastels and mail it to you. This is a deeply discounted price.

I am totally willing to earn your support.

Even if you cannot donate funding, please root of me and let others know of my story.

Thank you for considering to help.

Excited,

Gary Smith

gary@escapewithgary.com

story:
The Low Down:

Camp Cannonball is an interactive pirate ship structure built at the YMCA on Maui originally designed for Source! Maui Festival. The ship includes a bow that protrudes from the ground out towards the water. At Source! it serves as a hang out, stage and dance floor. This part of the ship remains intact all year round for the kids who attend to YMCA to enjoy. The ship also includes a crows nest with climbable rigging. Stunning views of the Keanae coastline can be seen including friends and whales. This year we are adding a flame cannon to the crows nest, and to repair and reinforce existing structures. The camp cannonball pirate ship is one of the most visited parts of the Source! festival.
Camp Cannonball Blog with Slide Show!
http://www.campcannonball.us/

What is SOURCE!?

SOURCE! is Maui’s largest annual multi-media arts, music and healing festival held at beautiful Camp Keanae on the wild tropical coast of Maui, Hawaii. SOURCE!  strengthens community bonds, is a place to create and share art, gifts, food and song and to dance. SOURCE! is entirely created with the energy and passion of all members who love to build community and create together. 


http://sourcemaui.com/

 

This is our Story and Mission for this year: 

Ahoy there mateys! This be the third year of building an interactive pirate ship and pirate camp complete with crows nest and climbable rigging. Source! is the venue and pirates be our theme.

We started with the crows nest 3 years ago at source and have expanded every year. Last year we built the bow (front part) of the ship and it provided a great dance floor for landlubbers and pirates alike.

This year we are stepping it up a notch and creating an arduino (hackable microchip system) controlled cannon replica that shoots fireballs! 

To accomplish our goals of fiery goodness and to strike fear into the hearts of our enemies we are asking for yer doubloons err donations!  

In addition to the flame cannon we will need a few parts to make our ship well shipshape! We will improve the rigging and shore up the bow and put a fresh coat of stain on the whole lot!

The great thing is that when Source! festival is over the ship gets to stay and becomes a structure that the YMCA camp can use. Talking to the groundskeeper he was enthusiastic about leaving the ship up for their regular kids camps and other events that take place on the grounds. Our sunken pirate ship gets to be functional installed art.

So not only does yer money go towards materials but it helps the children too!  Please donate yer doubloons and think of the children.

Rough estimate of Materials:
Cannon: 
Electronics: $60
Propane tank: $120
Expansion Tank: $50
Propane fittings and hoses: $60
Mounting hardware: $10

Refurbishing Equipment:
Rope: $80
Wood: $40
Concrete Footings: $45

Pirate Stickers: $135

Total: $600

Already over $1500 worth of materials have gone into making this interactive art installation come true. All the money raised here will go towards providing a home for wayward pirates.

story:
My dear friend Daniel Michael Viox, who is an artist whom I admire and respect, recently suffered the tragic destruction of over $10,000 of artwork by selfish vandals.

Though not all of us have the funds to purchase his work outright, we can band together to help fund Viox's efforts during this trying time.

Perhaps there is a small ray of hope that through researching restoration techniques, some of the work may be salvageable, but this will undoubtedly demand many hours of intense, painstaking and perhaps emotionally taxing labor, and may doubtless prove at times impossible.

Viox is a modern day Rothko amongst our midst who deserves our respect and our help, as well as our condolences.  He has done so much to help and inspire the artists in our community but has so seldom asked anything of us.  He is not asking us now for help, but we can share with him nonetheless, as a sign that we stand with him, that we believe in art, that we won't  let the bullies or the black holes win.


Sincerely, 

Serena Tideman

story:
Ladies and Gentlemen.

It has come to my attention that time is flying by and practically in the blink of an eye; it is already SENIOR YEAR. With that said, many important and exciting things are yet to come your way. Before being unleashed into the wonderful working world that is inching closer and closer, I realized I must follow my trend... of going out with a bang. As most of you who know me, I love to go over the top, exceed expectations, and believe no rules ever apply to anything... which leads me to my next exciting venture. As I check off my list of "to dos" before receiving my BFA in May, creating a Senior Show is one of the most important. Since I believe all good things come in pairs, (no brainer examples: chocolate/peanut butter, gold/silver, littleblackdress/staple pumps, sweatpants/hangover) I decided I too must make a pair. I am SO excited to say that I will be creating a long side one of the most talented, inspiring, and humble gents I know, Timothy Walter Martin. 
BOOM BANG
The best pair to unite since Batman and Robin.
Friendship Est. Sept 2011 to Present- Both MI born and raised- Midwest Hearts- Love for All things Lake Michigan
We decided to keep the legacy going and thus are conjuring up for you a combined Senior Show of not one but two magical nights of art, friendship, dance, and music. 
The show dates will be April 3 and 4th at ASIAN ARTS INITIATIVE in Philadelphia.
Times are TBD.
These two majestic evenings will be filled with original work from Tim and myself and something we are excited and proud to present. These past few years of creating, failing, succeeding, learning and growing have led us somewhere interesting and with that we want to share our journeys with you.

What We Need & What You Get 

So in order for all this magic to happen, we need YOU! Realistically though as young artists, we need help in funding our work and paying for space. A lot goes into making a show run smoothly and decorating a space that we all can enjoy which is why ANY and ALL help will be beyond appreciated. Ideally Tim and I are running this adventure straight from our pockets but have brains overflowing with ideas.. The ideas and the financial fees are not exactly lining up, but I know with your support this whole thing will come alive.  


The Breakdown

Your kind-hearted contributions will not only warm our hearts and provide us with a playground of opportunities to create for you the absolute BEST show.. but it will ideally go towards:
-Equipment rental fees (instruments, projectors, speakers, lighting etc)
-Hourly space rental fees
-Event Insurance fees
This is our last HOORAH to our artistic educations and the first of our many professional gigs which is why this is SO important to both of us. We have many amazing ideas in mind with collaborative work being one of thee most important.. thus we create for YOU and need YOUR good vibes to give life to this collaboration.

Also as a perk to all who donate $25 and above:
I Arianna Raquel Bickle will personally write you a hand-written letter of thanks and include a magical surprise trinket inside that will be unique to the individual who donated. If that doesn't sell you.. then man you are missing out because my trinket collection is award winning. #geratricstatus

I must also mention that any money donated over the goal and not used will be donated to NEDA- National Eating Disorder Association. As most of you know having struggled with anorexia as a youngin this foundation is near and dear to me. Anyway I can give back to those struggling with something that almost took my life.. I will and I hope you can stand behind me in that endeavor.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If donating is just not in your forecast these days  then you can take a moment to share this page with any family and friends who you think would be interested OR get your asses to Philly in April and see this dynamic duo of Arianna &Time in action! We promise it will be an inspiring, entertaining, and wonderful evening for ALL.

story:
As we prepare for our third year of experimental art and programming at Royal NoneSuch Gallery, we are reaching out to you, our extended network of friends, family, artists, colleagues and patrons to ask for support.

Royal NoneSuch Gallery is truly a labor of love. We are not motivated by commercial interests, but instead by working with artists and collaborators who are willing to take risks. The focus of our programs span exhibitions, conferences, workshops, live music and film screenings. 

Since 2009, we have supported more than one hundred local and national artists through over twenty art exhibitions and sixty events. In January 2010 the gallery was named â€˜Best New Artist Run Spaceâ€™ in Art Practical, and just last month, NPR affiliate KQED wrote that: 

â€˜Royal NoneSuch Gallery reflects a true alternative based on   collaboration, with a willingness to reinvent as space and time allow. Long may it reign.â€™


Our fundraising goal is to raise the $10,000 necessary to keep our doors open for a full year, $7,500 of which we are hoping to raise on this site! Any amount that you are able to give will make an enormous difference.


Sincerely,

Elizabeth Bernstein, Carrie Hott, Carey Lin, & Kathleen Quillian

story:
WHAT IT IS:

2014 IS A TIME CAPSULE PUBLICATION CONCEIVED & EDITED BY LUCA LO PINTO AND DESIGNED BY TOMMASO GARNER. IT WILL BE RELEASED IN AN EDITION OF 500 COPIES AND DISTRIBUTED INTERNATIONALLY.

MANIFESTO

Everything around us seems to run quickly. We are not regardless to that. We let us carry away by the speed that surrounds us. We try to travel as much as possible, to collect music as much as possible, to see as many movies as possible, to visit as many exhibitions as possible, to read as many books as possible. Everything as quick as we can. Nowadays time is gold. The new economy is based on the exploitation of this speed. There is no time to waste for knowing people, programs like facebook, twitter or instagram allow you to live the world while seated on a chair. We can do our shopping with a click, make music with a click, have sex with a click. The newspapers compete for the latest news. The news is more and more concise and nimble. The advertising adapts to time. The product is not didactly represented anymore, only suggested. It is unveiled with a veil. As regards this vortex of time, that gets us down, the concept of this project is to reverse the course. People don't read much: I make lots of pages. Paper is dead, internet is everything: I make a paper publication. And most of all, instead of competing for the first place, I compete for the last by making a publication that comes out every 5 years. 

The right period of time to verify the changes of taste, of language, of style and of the collective imaginary.

The publication is issued 5 yearly, but its contents has been prepared four years before that. It’s a time capsule. A bit like when as a kid you put a letter, a picture or a newspaper in a box, and then after years you look at it again with new eyes and another perspective. 

The title of the publication corresponds to the year of issue.

2014 is a dish composed of various ingredients, which I have assembled by following a very personal criterion. Artists projects, commissioned texts, republished texts, found photographs and old advertisements. There has been no limit imposed to the persons involved, neither of space nor of content. In this sense it took shape naturally, and not with a prepackaged grid like in books or magazines. Time is not the subject of this publication, only an instrument. An instrument to think about the influence of time and temporality in our lives and our way of looking at the world. 

featuring Giorgio Andreotta Calò - Carlo Antonelli - Cory Arcangel - Nina Beier - Pierre Bismuth - Carola Bonfili - Jeff Burton - Luca Cerizza - Spartacus Chetwynd -Stanislao Di Giugno - Rä di Martino - Ant Farm - Cyprien Gaillard - Mario Garcia Torres - Gelitin - Piero Golia - Fritz Haeg - Matthieu Laurette - Pablo Leon De La Barra - Andrea Lissoni - Raimundas Malasauskas - Michele Manfellotto - Valerio Mannucci - Aleksandra Mir - Jonathan Monk - Hanne Mugaas - Caterina Nelli - Carsten Nicolai - Olaf Nicolai - Luigi Ontani - Nicola Pecoraro - Paola Pivi - Emilio Prini - Sterling Ruby - Marten Spangberg - Francesco Stocchi - Terre Thaemlitz - Wolfgang Tillmans - Luca Vitone


WHO WE ARE:

Luca Lo Pinto (1981) is a curator based between Wien and Rome. He currently works as curator at the Kunsthalle Wien. He is founder and editor in chief of the magazine NERO. He is a regular contributor to the online cultural magazine Doppiozero. He has written for several catalogues and international magazines. He has curated a number of exhibitions that include, among others, Trapped in the closet (Carnegie Library/FRAC Champagne Ardenne, Reims, 2013); Antigrazioso (Palais de Toyko, Paris, 2013); Luigi Ontani-AnderSennoSogno (H.C. Andersen Museum, Rome 2012/2013); D’après Giorgio (Giorgio e Isa de Chirico Foundation, Rome 2012); When In Rome (IIC, Hammer Museum, La><Art, Los Angeles 2011); Roommates (MACRO Museum, Rome 2009); (NO) Vacancy (Maze Gallery, Turin 2008); 9 or 10 works I used to like, in no order (Monitor Gallery, Rome 2007); Maria Colao. A Bibliography/Conversation Pieces (Praz Museum, Rome 2006). In 2012 he curated Una Storia a program of talks at MACRO Museum. He has edited artist books by Olaf Nicolai, Luigi Ontani, Nicola Pecoraro, Emilio Prini, Alexandre Singh and Mario Garcia Torres. Recently he edited the book “Documenta 1955-2012. The endless story of two lovers”. He is a member of the advisory board of Depart Foundation.

Tommaso Garner (1984) is a graphic designer, art director and artist based in Milan. He realized essays, catalogues, coordinated identities, artist’s books and works in collaboration with: Alessio Ascari, Arthur Duff, Invernomuto, Marco Klefisch, Marcello Maloberti, Jacopo Miliani, Igor Muroni, Naba, Nike, Linda Fregni Nagler, Enea Righi, Andrea Sala, Giorgio Di Salvo, Mirko Smerdel, Marco Scotini, Super!, Luca Trevisani, Francesco Vezzoli, Andrea Viliani, Luca Vitone, Italo Zuffi. He took part in collective exhibitions: Who uses the space?, Isola Art center, Milano, 2005; Migre, Careof, Milano, 2006; Nothing but a show (book project), Castello Sforzesco, Milano 2009; Time Machine, MiArt, Milano 2010; Immagini Spezzate, Spazio Radio, Milano, 2010; Glitches, Milano 2010; Graphic Design World, Triennale Design Museum, Milano, 2011). He collaborates with Studio, Kaleidoscope and The End.


HOW THIS FUNDING HELPS:

As the project has grown in size, we realized that the costs for production will be a lot higher than we had hoped: we are looking at around €15.000 altogether, of which we can cover about €9.000. So that’s why we are asking for your help to cover the hole in our budget, so we can make sure that the book will the best it can possibly be.


WHERE WILL THE MONEY GO:

- Printing

- Distribution

- Website

- Commission Fees

He has curated a number of exhibitions that include, among others, Trapped in the closet (Carnegie Library/FRAC Champagne Ardenne, Reims, 2013); Antigrazioso (Palais de Toyko, Paris, 2013); Luigi Ontani-AnderSennoSogno (H.C. Andersen Museum, Rome 2012/2013); D’après Giorgio (Giorgio e Isa de Chirico Foundation, Rome 2012); When In Rome (IIC, Hammer Museum, La><Art, Los Angeles 2011); Roommates (MACRO Museum, Rome 2009); (NO) Vacancy (Maze Gallery, Turin 2008); 9 or 10 works I used to like, in no order (Monitor Gallery, Rome 2007); Maria Colao. A Bibliography/Conversation Pieces (Praz Museum, Rome 2006). In 2012 he curated Una Storia a program of talks at MACRO Museum. He has edited artist books by Olaf Nicolai, Luigi Ontani, Nicola Pecoraro, Emilio Prini, Alexandre Singh and Mario Garcia Torres. Recently he edited the book “Documenta 1955-2012. The endless story of two lovers”. He is a member of the advisory board of Depart Foundation.
Tommaso Garner (1984) is a graphic designer, art director and artist based in Milan. He realized essays, catalogues, coordinated identities, artist’s books and works in collaboration with: Alessio Ascari, Arthur Duff, Invernomuto, Marco Klefisch, Marcello Maloberti, Jacopo Miliani, Igor Muroni, Naba, Nike, Linda Fregni Nagler, Enea Righi, Andrea Sala, Giorgio Di Salvo, Mirko Smerdel, Marco Scotini, Super!, Luca Trevisani, Francesco Vezzoli, Andrea Viliani, Luca Vitone, Italo Zuffi. He took part in collective exhibitions: Who uses the space?, Isola Art center, Milano, 2005; Migre, Careof, Milano, 2006; Nothing but a show (book project), Castello Sforzesco, Milano 2009; Time Machine, MiArt, Milano 2010; Immagini Spezzate, Spazio Radio, Milano, 2010; Glitches, Milano 2010; Graphic Design World, Triennale Design Museum, Milano, 2011). He collaborates with Studio, Kaleidoscope and The End.
HOW THIS FUNDING HELPS:
As the project has grown in size, we realized that the costs for production will be a lot higher than we had hoped: we are looking at around €15.000 altogether, of which we can cover about €9.000. So that’s why we are asking for your help to cover the hole in our budget, so we can make sure that the book will the best it can possibly be.

WHERE WILL THE MONEY GO:
- Printing
- Distribution
- Website
- Commission Fees

story:
Short Summary

Hello! My name is Lisa Ann Sparks.  I am a fused glass artist based in Los Angeles.  I work out of my studio apartment and everything is handmade by me.  My work is mostly inspired by nature.  I am in love with the earth and what it has to show us.  I love working with glass because of it's natural beauty, and, as a bonus, I can always recycle it.  Glass itself is made from naturally occurring elements from the earth and I feel it does a beautiful job showcasing my designs inspired by nature.  

I have been working with glass for 10 years and selling my work fulltime for the last 5 years.  I sell both wholesale and retail.  The stores I sell to are boutiques, galleries and museums, and zoos and aquariums.  For retail, you can find me around LA at various farmer's markets, art festivals and street fairs.  

Which brings me to why I'm here asking for help.  The last year of trade shows has been very slow and this year has been the same.  It has been tough and I have been picking up odd jobs just to make ends meet.  I think it is time to try a different trade show and see if that brings in new business.  Autumn Fair is a trade show in Birmingham, England that focuses on the gift trade.  Not only is this a new set of potential buyers, it's also an amazing opportunity to share my handmade, nature-inspired, eco-conscious fused glass art with a global market.  How fabulous is that!  It is a great time to take this risk as the English Pound is very strong and the trend to import US made products into Europe is at it's height.  I asked the show for a small space and was lucky to get one.  Usually the layout is a 10' x 10' or nothing and that size booth is way out of my price range.  

I feel like this is a last ditch effort to try before throwing in the towel.  I do everything myself and I usually work around 12 hours a day.  Including markets, firings, creating new designs, updating my website, calling stores, accounting, etc. Having your own business is hard work and I am glad to do it if I can make it work.

I just need help with this next step.

What I Need & What You Get

This is what I need and why I asking for $7,200.  Remember when I said the Pound was strong...it's great for them, but for us, more expensive.  The exchange rate is currently 1.52.

$3,800.00  Booth space- includes carpet. (bare bones)

$  500.00  Lighting, electricity, furniture, display shelves

$  200.00  Decorating the booth (paint, decals, frames, hardware)

$1,200.00  Flight (I got a pass from a GREAT friend to use her discount.)

$  600.00  Hotel-  7 days- Staying outside of the city for a better rate

$  150.00  Rail pass, taxies, etc.

$  450.00  Food 3 meals- 7 days

$  150.00  Printing business cards and linesheets

$  150.00  Miscellaneous and I forgot about that's

Total = $7,200.00

PERKS

I have chosen the flexable funding plan so even if I don't reach my goal, everything helps and everyone will still receive their perk!

All of the Perks will be made to order by me and only me.

I am very grateful for all contributions and no one will go away empty handed.  I will also be sending updates before the show to introduce new designs and show everyone the booth set-up and the finished booth.  

I don't want you to have to read too much so please take a look at the perks to the right of this page and all of the photos (where needed) are in the Gallery Tab at the top of this page.  

Can't contribute money? No Problem. You can still help.

If you cannot contribute funds to this project, I completely understand. If you like my art work and would like to help in another way...please consider sharing this via the short link above. The more traffic, the more people see it, and it will be more likely to be featured on Indiegogo and inspire others to contribute.

Thank you so much for viewing my campaign and your support!

Lisa

story:
I realize these perks may not be appealing to some people, don't know why, but here are updated, better ones!

OK, here's the short of it.  JP has agreed that I (Phil) can be his minister if I pay him $485, don't believe me?  Here's the gchat transcript

 

JP: deposits?

 me: yeah

  minister

 JP: ah

1:28 PM sorry the only person that is awesome enough to marry JP

  is a JP

  your namesake isnt powerful enough

1:29 PM me: is a JP?

  you're gonna marry yourself?

1:30 PM JP: Justice of the Peace?

  JP

 me: yeah, i'm basically that

 JP: BASICALLY

 me: no religious denomination

 JP: but not TECHNICALLY

 me: one giant differece

1:31 PM i

  am

 JP: you're awful

  ?

 me: batman...

 JP: thats a big difference

 me: think about how much more aweome my ceremony would be versus some JP

1:32 PM and i'm sure i cost MUCH less

1:33 PM JP: ill tell you what

 me: mmmmyes

 JP: ill let you do it if you pay me

 me: fine, I will pay you %4

  $5

 JP: hahahaha'

  my fee is $350

 me: no, it's $5

  holy shit...

1:34 PM you just gave me an idea...

  are you committing to that $350...?

 JP: um

  maybe?

 me: no, i want a firm yes

 JP: well then i feel like i should make it $750

 me: $400

 JP: 500

1:35 PM me: $450

 JP: 500!

 me: $475

  in no shape of form are you going to find you someone who will pay YOU $475 to do your wedding

 JP: 500 and a picture of your mom in the shower

 me: $475, detroit pawn style!

 JP: 499

 me: i IMPLORE you to find someone who will pay YOU $475

1:36 PM JP: i think youre underestimating how awesome i am

 me: i think you're OVERestimating

  isaac can vouch for that

  $475

  you're nit picking over $24

  committ!

 JP: 489

 me: 4

  7

  5

 JP: 489!

1:37 PM its my lucky number

 me: $475.50

  no it is not

 JP: ok 485

 me: ok, $475

 JP: 485 last chance!

  3, 2, say yes

  ...1

 me: yes

 JP: ...say yes

 me: committed!

 JP: BOOM

 me: so we are firm at $485?

  when is the wedding?

 JP: yes

1:38 PM i dont know like october 2014

 me: awesome

  give me until january 1st, 2014 to raise the money

 

See, it's real.  Sorry, Heidi.

So clearly if you're attending the Pietrella-Zengel nuptials you'll need to know about me!  I'm Phil Teixeira.  Depending on who you ask, generally a nice guy, can be a bit much at times, but usually means well.  My hobbies include eating, making life difficult for John Lallier, creating elaborate internet shenanigans, (don't be fooled though, this is real), and ministering THE BEST WEDDINGS EVER.

If you'd like me to bring my special brand of joy to this special day, then please donate!

Don't thinking I'm scheming you by having the minimum donation at $550, indiegogo takes anywhere between 4%-9%, but I promise every penny of this will go towards the future Mr. and Mrs. Pietrella (or whatever Heidi prefers, I'd actually prefer Mr. and Mrs. Zengel).

 

I have until January 1st, 2014 to raise this money, so I will keep running it until then!  I'll be adding payment via Pay Pal soon!

story:
C/S (Con/Safos)

C/S or Con/Safos (with respect) is a year long project along the banks of the Los Angeles River, created as part of the Bowtie Project on California State Parks land. Over the summer of 2014 my father and I, with help from the rest of my family and some friends, made 1500 adobe bricks which were used as part of site-specific performance. Now I am going to use these handmade bricks to build  2 intersecting adobe walls that will be sealed, primed and prepped for painting. Throughout the course of a year local graffiti artists, painters and sculptors will be invited to design, paint, and build onto the surface of Con/Safos. This work will provide an open sanctioned space for painters and graffiti artists to create temporal artworks. 

C/S Mock-Up with works by Timo Fahler and Iris Hu

I am partnering up with three organizations: Clockshop, an arts organization, California State Parks, and Self Help Graphics & Art, a popular and vital community resource for the creation and presentation of Chicano/Mexicano art and culture in East LA to create this work. Self Help will invite each participating artists to partake in their Atelier Program where they will print a limited edition serigraphic print inspired by their work at C/S. SHGA will also be conducting onsite experiments creating dyes from native plants to use in printing, thus producing their first ever site-specific edition and infusing each print with the feeling and life of the LA river. 

Photo by Marcel Hurtut at Self-Help Graphics

The Los Angeles River has long been a contested site in many forms. As of  2008, the Los Angeles Graffiti Abatement Program resulted in the removal of much of the historic graffiti that lined the embankments and walls along the river. It erased not only a significant history of artistic production specific to Los Angeles, but with it dislocated and disbanded a community whose primary creative forum was found along these banks. This collaboration is designed to highlight a history of displacement along the river, support local artists who historically lack organizational/ institutional and financial support, create a safe platform for artists to practice, build creative networks, and to help them explore exhibition opportunities inside and outside of traditional art spaces.

Apprx. Location of C/S


Con/Safos will be free and open to the public to view, up to and while the works are being created.

List of Participating Artists (names added as confirmed):
Sarah Dougherty
Timo Fahler 
Juan Manuel Gudiño
HOODsisters
Iris Hu 
Leo Limon
The Maricon Collective
Local Bowtie Artists

Onsite Graffiti at the Bowtie Project

Rafa Esparza is a multidisciplinary artist. His work ranges in medium from installation, sculpture to drawing, painting; and most predominantly live performance. Woven into Esparza’s bodies of work are his interests in history, personal narratives, and kinship. He is inspired by his own relationship to colonization and the disrupted genealogies that come forth as a result of this. Esparza has performed in a variety of spaces ranging from community engaged places such as AIDS Project Los Angeles, to galleries including Los Angeles Contemporary Exhibitions, Highways Performance Space, REDCAT, Human Resources, SOMArts and most recently public sites through out the city of L.A. He is a recipient of an Emerging Artist 2014 California Community Foundation Fellowship for Visual Artists. 

Rafa Esparza Performance Summer 2014

For almost 40 years, Self Help Graphics & Art has emerged as the leading visual arts cultural center which serves the predominantly Chicano/Mexicano community of Los Angeles. Located in the heart of East Los Angeles, and surrounded by a local population of over two million Chicanos/Mexicanos, Self Help Graphics & Art has been a popular and vital community resource of for the creation and presentation of Chicano/Mexicano art and culture in East LA. SHGA is a nationally recognized center for Latino arts that develops and nurtures artists in printmaking. It seeks to advance Latino art broadly through programming, exhibitions and outreach to diverse audiences in East Los Angeles and beyond. SHGA seeks to identify and engage young and emerging artists from the community in all aspects of its activities.

Clockshop is a multifaceted arts organization that works at the intersection of politics, urban space, and cultural production to explore the forces that shape our lived environment. Clockshop programs events and screenings, and produces artist projects and conversations. Clockshop is a 501 (c)(3) nonprofit organization, based in Elysian Valley.


CA State Parks Ranger Luis Rincon, Clockshop Director Julia Meltzer and members of the Bowtie Project Community

California State Parks contains the largest and most diverse natural and cultural heritage holdings of any state agency in the nation. State park units include underwater preserves, reserves, and parks; redwood, rhododendron, and wildlife reserves; state beaches, recreation areas, wilderness areas, and reservoirs; state historic parks, historic homes, Spanish era adobe buildings, including museums, visitor centers, cultural reserves, and preserves; as well as lighthouses, ghost towns,  waterslides, conference centers, and off-highway vehicle parks. These parks protect and preserve an unparalleled collection of culturally and environmentally sensitive structures and habitats, threatened plant and animal species, ancient Native American sites, historic structures and artifacts . . . the best of California's natural and cultural history.

The Bowtie Project

The Bowtie Project is a collaboration between Clockshop and California State Parks to activate a 19-acre post-industrial lot known as The Bowtie, located along the LA River in Northeast Los Angeles. Owned by CA State parks since 2003 and closed to the public for over a decade, Clockshop has been invited to bring a broad and experimental blend of artists’ projects and collaborations to this overlooked piece of land.

This partnership is made possible with support from California State Parks Foundation, the Metropolitan Water District, the National Park Service, and the Mountains Recreation and Conservation Authority.

View of Rafa Esparza's handmade bricks on the Bowtie Project 

Northern facing view of the Bowtie Project

Production & Exhibition Schedule

C/S construction will commence mid January, with the surface set for it’s first painting to begin on February 1st. A new mural will begin production at the top of every other month starting in February and continuing through the rest of the year as follows:

April 1st, 2015

June 1st, 2015

August 1st, 2015

October 1st, 2015

November 1st, 2015

An unveiling event will coincide with the completion of each piece with an open invitation to the public. Atelier dates with Self-Help Graphics have yet to be determined.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $7,500 to make this project happen.
Here's how that money gets broken down: 

$6,000 - Artists Honorariums

$1,000 - Paint and construction materials

$525 - Indiegogo Fees

THE PERKS

$10: Publicly thanked on behalf of Artist on Clockshop's website

$25: Your name gets painted onto Con/Safos, photographed, and shared publicly via your social platform of choice.


$50: Special Edition C/S T-Shirt

$75: 11x14 Gold Mas Puto Wood Block Print


$100: Self Help Graphics & Art Small Limited Edition Serigrah Print

$250: 2 tickets for Clockshop Dinner/Music Series (see ex. of past event)

$500: Self Help Graphics & Art - Con/Safos: Limited Edition Serigraph Print

 $1,000: Bird from Rafa Esparza’s Love Birds Series

The Impact

Con/Safos will help foster networks of support for artists who seek to or are actively making public art by providing a unique multimedia platform that is both public and accessible as well as financial support. SHGA has been a  generative space in this way for nearly 40 years and has provided countless services and opportunities to emerging artists whom are now some of the cities most prolific cultural producers. In thinking about access and my relationship to land, I have progressively made more work engaging audiences outside of traditional art spaces and in this effort to have a targeted conversation with “place”  and communities who often don’t access art in museums and galleries. With your help Con/Safos will connect artists with new avenues to explore their possibilities as makers inside and outside of mainstream art markets.

Artist Leo Limon, Image Courtesy of UCSB
Risks & Challenges

The Bowtie Project is public land, a shared space, and this presents a few concrete challenges. Here’s an example: after the first day of making bricks with my father at the bowtie last summer, I came to discover a batch of bricks run over by a dirt bike. The bricks were unsalvageable. We had spent one full day working in the blazing sun to make them, and the thought of explaining to my father what had happened was more disappointing to me than the fact that they had been destroyed. But as I scraped up the crumbled, heavy chunks of damp clay from those 68 destroyed bricks, a realization came to me that would color my relationship with this piece of land into the weeks ahead. The realization that this land is a shared space and utilized by many in different ways directly inspired the Con/Safos project. 



At the Bowtie Project
From the people that live there, to the students that cut through the park to get to and from school, to the neighbors who walk their pets in the morning and sunset, to the kayakers rowing downstream in packs, to the veteranos who proudly wear their neighborhood on their bodies, to the taggers who claim it as their own by writing on it. I put up signs in English in Spanish explaining what my family and I were doing at the park, moved our workstation out of the open space and throughout the rest of the 3-4 weeks the bricks were left unharmed. I got to meet many of the regulars that pass through the park, many of whom live there. I had conversations with them, had lunch with them, as we shared bits of each others lives with one another. The challenge and the opportunity I see in Con/Safos is to engage a community that has been criminalized. The sanctioning of the walls and making them accessible is part of the way I plan to engage graffiti artists; where the writing on the walls will itself can be the mode of communication and an invitation for collaboration.


Other Ways You Can Help

You can help us GREATLY by spreading the word about Con/Safos. Email it to you contacts, share the link on Facebook, Twitter, Ello, Instagram, post it on your blogs, Tumblrs, and text it your friends. Be part of the community of supporters that will make this project a reality and come join us at the Bowtie Project once Con/Safos is up and running!


Rafa Esparza at the Bowtie Project in a Maricon Collective jersey


Thank you to 2Mex and Abstract Rude 
Follow 2Mex on Twitter https://twitter.com/2mexla

"Coat of Paint" taken from Abstract Rude's P.A.I.N.T lp available online at https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/p.a.i.n.t./id306865459

Visit abstractrude.com for info on Ab Rude

Photo by Marcel Hurtut at Self-Help GraphicsThe Los Angeles River has long been a contested site in many forms. As of  2008, the Los Angeles Graffiti Abatement Program resulted in the removal of much of the historic graffiti that lined the embankments and walls along the river. It erased not only a significant history of artistic production specific to Los Angeles, but with it dislocated and disbanded a community whose primary creative forum was found along these banks. This collaboration is designed to highlight a history of displacement along the river, support local artists who historically lack organizational/ institutional and financial support, create a safe platform for artists to practice, build creative networks, and to help them explore exhibition opportunities inside and outside of traditional art spaces.


Apprx. Location of C/S
Con/Safos will be free and open to the public to view, up to and while the works are being created.List of Participating Artists (names added as confirmed):Sarah DoughertyTimo Fahler Juan Manuel GudiñoHOODsistersIris Hu Leo LimonThe Maricon CollectiveLocal Bowtie Artists


Onsite Graffiti at the Bowtie Project

Rafa Esparza is a multidisciplinary artist. His work ranges in medium from installation, sculpture to drawing, painting; and most predominantly live performance. Woven into Esparza’s bodies of work are his interests in history, personal narratives, and kinship. He is inspired by his own relationship to colonization and the disrupted genealogies that come forth as a result of this. Esparza has performed in a variety of spaces ranging from community engaged places such as AIDS Project Los Angeles, to galleries including Los Angeles Contemporary Exhibitions, Highways Performance Space, REDCAT, Human Resources, SOMArts and most recently public sites through out the city of L.A. He is a recipient of an Emerging Artist 2014 California Community Foundation Fellowship for Visual Artists. 


Rafa Esparza Performance Summer 2014
For almost 40 years, Self Help Graphics & Art has emerged as the leading visual arts cultural center which serves the predominantly Chicano/Mexicano community of Los Angeles. Located in the heart of East Los Angeles, and surrounded by a local population of over two million Chicanos/Mexicanos, Self Help Graphics & Art has been a popular and vital community resource of for the creation and presentation of Chicano/Mexicano art and culture in East LA. SHGA is a nationally recognized center for Latino arts that develops and nurtures artists in printmaking. It seeks to advance Latino art broadly through programming, exhibitions and outreach to diverse audiences in East Los Angeles and beyond. SHGA seeks to identify and engage young and emerging artists from the community in all aspects of its activities.


Clockshop is a 
multifaceted arts organization that works at the intersection of 
politics, urban space, and cultural production to explore the forces 
that shape our lived environment. Clockshop programs events and 
screenings, and produces artist projects and conversations. Clockshop is
 a 501 (c)(3) nonprofit organization, based in Elysian Valley. 


CA State Parks Ranger Luis Rincon, Clockshop Director Julia Meltzer and members of the Bowtie Project Community
California State Parks contains the largest and most diverse natural and cultural heritage holdings of any state agency in the nation. State park units include underwater preserves, reserves, and parks; redwood, rhododendron, and wildlife reserves; state beaches, recreation areas, wilderness areas, and reservoirs; state historic parks, historic homes, Spanish era adobe buildings, including museums, visitor centers, cultural reserves, and preserves; as well as lighthouses, ghost towns,  waterslides, conference centers, and off-highway vehicle parks. These parks protect and preserve an unparalleled collection of culturally and environmentally sensitive structures and habitats, threatened plant and animal species, ancient Native American sites, historic structures and artifacts . . . the best of California's natural and cultural history.


The Bowtie ProjectThe Bowtie Project is a collaboration between Clockshop and California State Parks to activate a 19-acre post-industrial lot known as The Bowtie, located along the LA River in Northeast Los Angeles. Owned by CA State parks since 2003 and closed to the public for over a decade, Clockshop has been invited to bring a broad and experimental blend of artists’ projects and collaborations to this overlooked piece of land.
This partnership is made possible with support from California State Parks Foundation, the Metropolitan Water District, the National Park Service, and the Mountains Recreation and Conservation Authority.


View of Rafa Esparza's handmade bricks on the Bowtie Project 
Northern facing view of the Bowtie Project

Production & Exhibition ScheduleC/S construction will commence mid January, with the surface set for it’s first painting to begin on February 1st. A new mural will begin production at the top of every other month starting in February and continuing through the rest of the year as follows:
April 1st, 2015
June 1st, 2015
August 1st, 2015
October 1st, 2015
November 1st, 2015An unveiling event will coincide with the completion of each piece with an open invitation to the public. Atelier dates with Self-Help Graphics have yet to be determined.
   What We Need & What You Get


Our goal is to raise $7,500 to make this project happen. Here's how that money gets broken down: $6,000 - Artists Honorariums
$1,000 - Paint and construction materials
$525 - Indiegogo Fees
THE PERKS
$10: Publicly thanked on behalf of Artist on Clockshop's website
$25: Your name gets painted onto Con/Safos, photographed, and shared publicly via your social platform of choice.




$50: Special Edition C/S T-Shirt

$75: 11x14 Gold Mas Puto Wood Block Print


$100: Self Help Graphics & Art Small Limited Edition Serigrah Print

$250: 2 tickets for Clockshop Dinner/Music Series (see ex. of past event)

$500: Self Help Graphics & Art - Con/Safos: Limited Edition Serigraph Print


  $1,000: Bird from Rafa Esparza’s Love Birds Series

   The Impact
 Con/Safos will help foster networks of support for artists who seek to or are actively making public art by providing a unique multimedia platform that is both public and accessible as well as financial support. SHGA has been a  generative space in this way for nearly 40 years and has provided countless services and opportunities to emerging artists whom are now some of the cities most prolific cultural producers. In thinking about access and my relationship to land, I have progressively made more work engaging audiences outside of traditional art spaces and in this effort to have a targeted conversation with “place”  and communities who often don’t access art in museums and galleries. With your help Con/Safos will connect artists with new avenues to explore their possibilities as makers inside and outside of mainstream art markets.



Artist Leo Limon, Image Courtesy of UCSB

Risks & Challenges
  
The Bowtie Project is public land, a shared space, and this presents a few concrete challenges. Here’s an example: after the first day of making bricks with my father at the bowtie last summer, I came to discover a batch of bricks run over by a dirt bike. The bricks were unsalvageable. We had spent one full day working in the blazing sun to make them, and the thought of explaining to my father what had happened was more disappointing to me than the fact that they had been destroyed. But as I scraped up the crumbled, heavy chunks of damp clay from those 68 destroyed bricks, a realization came to me that would color my relationship with this piece of land into the weeks ahead. The realization that this land is a shared space and utilized by many in different ways directly inspired the Con/Safos project. 


At the Bowtie ProjectFrom the people that live there, to the students that cut through the park to get to and from school, to the neighbors who walk their pets in the morning and sunset, to the kayakers rowing downstream in packs, to the veteranos who proudly wear their neighborhood on their bodies, to the taggers who claim it as their own by writing on it. I put up signs in English in Spanish explaining what my family and I were doing at the park, moved our workstation out of the open space and throughout the rest of the 3-4 weeks the bricks were left unharmed. I got to meet many of the regulars that pass through the park, many of whom live there. I had conversations with them, had lunch with them, as we shared bits of each others lives with one another. The challenge and the opportunity I see in Con/Safos is to engage a community that has been criminalized. The sanctioning of the walls and making them accessible is part of the way I plan to engage graffiti artists; where the writing on the walls will itself can be the mode of communication and an invitation for collaboration.   
Other Ways You Can Help 
You can help us GREATLY by spreading the word about Con/Safos. Email it to you contacts, share the link on Facebook, Twitter, Ello, Instagram, post it on your blogs, Tumblrs, and text it your friends. Be part of the community of supporters that will make this project a reality and come join us at the Bowtie Project once Con/Safos is up and running!
Rafa Esparza at the Bowtie Project in a Maricon Collective jersey
Thank you to 2Mex and Abstract Rude Follow 2Mex on Twitter https://twitter.com/2mexla
"Coat of Paint" taken from Abstract Rude's P.A.I.N.T lp available online at https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/p.a.i.n.t./id306865459
Visit abstractrude.com for info on Ab Rude

story:
Mi chiamo Mattia e sono un ragazzo tetraplegico dalla nascita .

Ho 25 anni. Sono allegro, ottimista e socievole.

Da circa 4 anni, grazie al mio papà, ho iniziato a dipingere quadri utilizzando la mia sedia a motore a cui sono stati applicati rulli e pennelli. Mi diverto molto a giocare con i colori: roteando con la mia sedia lascio impresse curve, onde, linee con effetti incredibili e imprevedibili! I miei estimatori dicono che i miei quadri sono "magici". Esprimono il mio entusiasmo, la mia gioia di vivere e sono il risultato delle esperienze che vivo, dei posti che vedo, delle belle persone che incontro.

Il mio unico modo per spostarmi in modo autonomo è utilizzando la sedia a rotelle a motore che modestamente guido con grande abilità, purtroppo le barriere sono tante e molti posti mi sono preclusi: strade sconnesse, gradini, prati, sentieri, spiagge......ma qualche anno fa ho scovato su internet una sedia sorprendente: la X8 EXTREME ! Una vera folgorazione, è stato amore a prima vista! Quella era la sedia per me, la sedia che da tanto sognavo! Già mi vedevo all'Isuledda, campeggio dove vado tutti gli anni, a impazzare ovunque e finalmente poter seguire Andrea Zambaldi, il capoanimatore mio idolo, e tutti i ragazzi e RAGAZZE dell'animazione, la "Soul Action"proprio dappertutto, anche in spiaggia!

Il grosso problema è che questa sedia è la Ferrari delle sedie a rotelle e costa come una macchina. Papà e mamma, che devo onestamente dire che di soldi per me ne spendono tanti, continuano a glissare e dirmi "si Mat bella bella, risparmiamo i soldi e poi vediamo..."

Insomma io ci tengo proprio tanto, è un pò come per voi le gambe, penso che potete capirmi....quindi un grazie di cuore a chi mi aiuta a comprarla e grazie anche a chi comunque condivide la mia campagna e la fa conoscere ad altri.

GRAZIE!!!!!!!!



 A very special wheelchair for a special artist.
 
My name is Mattia and I'm tetraplegic since birth.
I'm a very happy boy and I love colours. Thanks to my dad and my electronic wheelchair I make paintings, in order to express my emotions and feelings.
My biggest dream is to own the X8 extreme wheelchair because that will give me the opportunity to go everywhere : on the beach, on the stairs, along countryside paths and to knock down every bondaries so that my enthusiasm and my inspirations can grow.
I'm tetraplegic and my autonomy is strictly lead to the wheelchair.
I'm incredibly optimistic, sociable. I love travel and meet people.
Around 4 years ago I started to paint using my electronic wheelchair that has been modified by my dad, who attached on it a lot of brushes and rolls.
I have a lot of fun in doing this, I like to play with colours, finding unexpected results.
My work fully express my enthusiasm and my energy and they are the result of all the experences that I have done in my life.

story:
Kort introduktion

I december 2015 släppte jag min allra första standup-EP på Spotify. "Korta skämt" fick ett varmt mottagande och det gjorde mig jätteglad. Dagen efter inspelning satte jag mig ner och började skriva på uppföljaren.

Sedan började jag fundera. Tänk om jag inte bara skulle släppa en ny skiva i år? Tänk om jag skulle släppa tre? Jag räknade på det och visst skulle det bli svettigt. Visst skulle det bli väldigt många nya skämt att skriva. Men det skulle absolut gå.

Så nu arbetar jag på min skämt-trilogi. Jag är redan en bra bit in i första EP:n av de tre. Så stötta gärna detta projekt med en summa du finner rimlig. Det kommer bli det roligaste jag någonsin gjort.

Var pengarna behövs

Pengarna jag försöker samla in ska gå till ljudinspelaren Zoom H4n, samt täcka mina resekostnader.
Inräknat finns en skrivperiod på tre månader för varje skiva med ytterligare en månads marginal.

story:
PROJECT

The continuation of the PDX Art Guide takes our ongoing publication and puts it in the hands of artists to showcase their own style for special quarterly releases.

Our Art Guide is a project that highlights art spaces in Portland, Oregon. The project's goal is to both feature art spaces important to the community and to help expand the visibility of selected artists. The publication also looks to unite art spaces, museums, galleries, and project spaces in a risograph publication designed in each artists' interpretation which will be issued quarterly.

We're hoping to reach our fundraising goal so that we can offer these guides free to the public. These quarterly publications will be available at select establishments all around the Portland area.

We're expanding our scope beyond just documenting the contemporary art scene and sharing it on our Instagram, our main social media platform. This project aims to accomplish this movement outside digital media to something physical and tangible for the community.

 

SUPPORT

Your contribution will greatly assist in reaching the goals of our project. Contributions will go towards the costs of; paper; ink, printing, artist stipends, and creative content. We're hoping to print at least 100 copies of each artists' collaborative guide.

This project is for the Portland arts community, and we hope that we have your support with this project. So we can continue to produce and expand on projects that uplift the arts community.

Additional funds we receive beyond our goal will be instrumental to the realization of each artists' collaborations and materials. Even if you can't make a donation, we hope that you please spread the word about this project. We appreciate any contribution however big or small, it means so much to us!

 

SELECTED 2018 ARTISTS

SPRING: JODIE CAVALIER

Jodie Cavalier is an interdisciplinary artist working in Portland, Oregon. Cavalier received her BA from the University of California, Berkeley and MFA from Pacific Northwest College of Art in Portland, Oregon. She has participated in residencies at; the Center for Land Use Interpretation in Wendover, Utah in 2014, Wassaic in 2016, and AZ West Wagon Encampment in 2017. Her work has been exhibited at the Schneider Museum (Ashland), the deYoung Museum (San Francisco), Pacific Film Archive (Berkeley), CoCA (Seattle), EXO Project Space (Chicago), Städelschule (Frankfurt), Anytime Department in (Cincinnati), among others.

SUMMER: AMY BAY 

Amy Bay (b. Elkhart, IN) is a painter based in Portland, OR. Bay holds a BFA from The School of The Art Institute of Chicago and an MFA from Winchester School of Art. She also completed the London-based Turps Banana Correspondence Course for painters. Bay's heavily worked paintings use motifs and imagery that draw from decorative sources. She values the subjective, the emotional, error and mishap. She is interested in the mutability of the picturesque and conventional feminine imagery. Bay has exhibited her work at venues in the Pacific Northwest including UNA and Occasional Gallery as well as throughout New York City at Peninsula Art Space, The Painting Center, The Drawing Center, Printed Matter, Brooklyn Public Library, and The Bronx Museum of the Arts. She has shown internationally in group and solo shows and has been awarded grants and projects from the Regional Art and Culture Council, The Lower East Side Printshop, Dieu Donné Papermill and Women's Studio Workshop. She teaches at Portland Community College and Village Home Education Resource Center. Bay will have a solo exhibition at Melanie Flood Projects in August of 2018.

FALL: LAUREN BECK 

Lauren Beck is an artist working in Portland, Oregon by way of Seattle, Washington. Beck graduated with a Bachelor of Art from Pacific Northwest College of Art in 2016. Her recent work uses photography and installation to illustrate the idea of "Vacation"--and all the privilege, societal concerns and access it connotates to be able to vacation. Her work has been shown at Pacific Northwest College of Art in numerous group exhibitions. Beck currently builds on her background in photography by processing film at Citizen's, and tending and caring for plants at Appetite.  

WINTER: LAUREN WILSON

Lauren Wilson is an artist from Oakland, California currently working in Bend, Oregon. George received her BA from the Oregon College of Art and Craft in Portland, Oregon. Her paintings have continually been focused on portraiture and were featured in New American Paintings No.115. When she’s not painting she’s baking the best croissants around and being walked by her two giant dogs. Awards; 2014 New American Paintings, Pacific Coast Issue #115, 2013 Gamblin Paint Award, Gamblin Paint Company, Portland, Oregon, 2011 Hoffman Gallery Juried show, 1st Place for painting Bathtub, Oregon College of Art and Craft, Portland, Oregon.
 

PROJECT PARTNERS

CONCEPT, CREATIVE & ORGANIZER: ASHLEY GIFFORD

Ashley Gifford is an interdisciplinary artist, writer, and digitalist from Honolulu, Hawaii currently based in Portland, Oregon. She lived in Westchester County, New York for several years before relocating to the West Coast. She's the Founder and Creative Director of Art & About PDX---an artist-run initiative and platform documenting Portland, Oregon's contemporary art scene through photographic, written, and digital media.

DESIGN: JAMES CASEY

James is a graphic designer from Honolulu, HI living in Portland, OR. He enjoys all things print and type, experimentation, and collaboration. Currently pursuing a degree in graphic design and communications at Portland State University. He dreams of owning a shiba inu one day.

PRINTED AT OUTLET IN NORTHEAST PORTLAND
